_meta.instructions: Each industry contains an array of archetypes. To add a new industry, copy the structure of an existing one. To add a new archetype, copy an existing archetype object and update all fields. Radar values are 0‚Äì100. CX principle scores are 1‚Äì10.

fields_guide.name: Evocative archetype name, e.g. 'Truth Seekers'
fields_guide.latin: Latin motto with English meaning in parentheses
fields_guide.description: 2-3 sentences. Who they are behaviorally. Implied first person: I am‚Ä¶
fields_guide.goals: 2-3 sentences. What success looks like. I want‚Ä¶
fields_guide.needs: 2-3 sentences. What they actually do. I do‚Ä¶
fields_guide.touchpoints: 2-3 sentences. Which channels and why. I use‚Ä¶
fields_guide.cx_principles.higher_order: Recognition, Integrity, Expectations, Empathy, Emotions ‚Äî scored 1‚Äì10
fields_guide.cx_principles.basic_order: Resolution, Speed, Effort, Enablement, Convenience ‚Äî scored 1‚Äì10
fields_guide.goals_radar: 9 axes: Recognition, New Image, Future Growth, New Lifestyle, Family Place, Service & Support, Risks & Reassurance, Enablement & Tools, Guidance & Advice
fields_guide.needs_radar: 8 axes: Information, Content & Inspiration, Offers & Price, Payment Options, Guidance & Advice, Enablement & Tools, Risks & Reassurance, Service & Support
fields_guide.touchpoints_radar: 8 axes: Online Search, Showrooms, Brand Website, Partner/Broker, Social Media, Aggregators, Community, Word of Mouth
fields_guide.expectations: Array of strings ‚Äî what they expect from the experience
fields_guide.barriers: Array of strings ‚Äî what holds them back
fields_guide.drivers: Array of strings ‚Äî what motivates them
fields_guide.triggers: Array of strings ‚Äî what sets them into motion
fields_guide.important_steps: Array of strings ‚Äî key stages in their journey
fields_guide.solution_principles: Array of strings ‚Äî HTML allowed for emphasis. Format: 'Because they need X, the experience must be Y.'

real_estate.label: Real Estate & Property
real_estate.description: Buyers, renters and investors navigating one of life's highest-stakes decisions.

archetypes.name: Home, Sweet Home
archetypes.description: I lead a busy life and one of my key priorities is to take care of my family and its many needs. A property purchase is going to provide security, protection and comfort my family deserves. It's a one-shot decision and I need to be reassured that it will secure my family's future financially and protect its privacy.
archetypes.goals: My goal is to find a home for every family member that will not just be a place to live, but a reward and recognition for us as a family ‚Äî with a personal touch for every member. Something that will highlight our individualities and bring us together.
archetypes.needs: To reach that goal, I am doing a lot of research, exploration and deal-hunting, for which I need guidance and content. I want to learn more about smart ways of maintaining a better work-life balance and I need personalisation options as important as the community I will be buying in.
archetypes.touchpoints: Friends, agents that I trust, social media and online search are important channels. But even more so it's the opportunity to touch and feel what my future home will look like. I don't want to be rushed, good choice takes time, I want to be perceived as the one who makes the decision ‚Äî not the developer or agent.
expectations: Time management
Availability
Clarity on costs
Location / distance
barriers: Move-in data
Availability
Price
Location / distance
Payment options
solution_principles: Because they need guidance and content to make every family member happy, the experience must be guided, but full of opportunities for personalisation.
Because they need a secure way to finalize the transaction to avoid putting financials at risk, the experience has to be reassuring and risk-free.
Because they need inspiration on how to organize their future home to fulfill the family dreams, the experience has to be adventurous, creating opportunities to discover and try new things.

archetypes.name: The Wealth Guardian
archetypes.description: I see property not as a home but as a vehicle for wealth preservation and generational transfer. Every decision is filtered through return on investment, capital appreciation and risk mitigation. I am analytical, patient and rarely impressed by aesthetics alone ‚Äî numbers must speak first.
archetypes.goals: I want to build a portfolio that outlasts market volatility, delivers reliable yield and appreciates over a ten-year horizon. Recognition matters to me as a sophisticated investor, not as a homeowner.
archetypes.needs: I research macroeconomic indicators, track developer track records and compare yield data obsessively. I need transparent financial modelling, off-plan data and direct access to senior advisors who understand investment logic.
archetypes.touchpoints: I rely on financial publications, industry reports, private banking relationships and referrals from trusted investment networks. Showrooms are largely irrelevant ‚Äî data rooms and one-on-one briefings are where I make decisions.
expectations: Transparent yield data
Developer track record
Legal clarity
Dedicated investment advisor
barriers: Lack of financial transparency
Unclear exit strategy
Developer credibility
Currency and regulatory risk
solution_principles: Because they need data transparency before trust, the experience must lead with facts, not feelings ‚Äî numbers before narratives.
Because they fear reputational and financial risk, the brand must position itself as a credible, track-record-backed partner rather than a sales operation.
Because they value time as much as capital, the journey must eliminate friction and provide senior-level access at every critical decision point.

archetypes.name: The Status Architect
archetypes.latin: Ostendo Ergo Sum (I Show Therefore I Am)
archetypes.description: I purchase property as a statement ‚Äî of arrival, of taste, of a life well-built. The brand behind the development matters as much as the unit itself. I want what others aspire to, and I want to feel that exclusivity in every interaction from first enquiry to handover.
archetypes.goals: I want a property that elevates my social currency, is photographable, and is located in an address that commands instant recognition. I want the purchase process itself to feel premium ‚Äî discreet, attentive, and tailored to me personally.
archetypes.needs: I engage with luxury lifestyle media, follow design-forward developers on social channels, and expect white-glove treatment at every touchpoint. I am drawn to limited availability, signature architecture and curated lifestyle amenities.
archetypes.touchpoints: Instagram, architecture publications, luxury lifestyle events and private previews are my primary channels. Word of mouth from peers I respect carries enormous weight. I expect a dedicated relationship manager ‚Äî not a generic sales agent.
expectations: White-glove service
Exclusive previews
Design curation
Dedicated relationship manager
barriers: Generic sales approach
Crowd-sourced availability
Impersonal communication
Visible price negotiation
solution_principles: Because they buy with emotion and justify with logic, the experience must engage their sense of self before presenting the product.
Because they fear being treated as just another buyer, every touchpoint must be personalised, named, and curated to feel exclusive.
Because they are influenced by peers and aesthetics, the brand must create shareable, visual, prestige-signalling moments throughout the journey.

archetypes.name: The Brave First-Timer
archetypes.latin: Primum Gressum Facio (I Take the First Step)
archetypes.description: I am entering the property market for the first time, navigating a world of jargon, paperwork and financial commitment that feels overwhelming. I want to get it right but I am scared of getting it wrong. I need someone to trust, not someone to sell to me.
archetypes.goals: I want to own my first home ‚Äî a place that is truly mine, that gives me stability and a sense of achievement. I want to feel proud, not fooled. The experience of buying should feel as good as the moment I get the keys.
archetypes.needs: I research extensively online before speaking to anyone. I read forums, watch YouTube walkthroughs and compare mortgage calculators. I need step-by-step guidance, plain-language explanations and reassurance that I am not missing something critical.
archetypes.touchpoints: Google, YouTube, property aggregator apps and Reddit-style community forums are where I spend most of my research time. When I am ready to engage, I need a human ‚Äî but one who educates rather than pressures. WhatsApp and live chat feel less threatening than formal sales offices.
expectations: Plain-language guidance
No-pressure communication
Step-by-step process clarity
Transparent pricing
barriers: Financial jargon
Fear of making wrong decision
Lack of knowledge
Sales pressure
solution_principles: Because they are overwhelmed by complexity, the experience must simplify every step into plain, human language with no assumed knowledge.
Because they fear being misled, integrity must be built into every communication ‚Äî transparent fees, honest timelines, no hidden conditions.
Because the emotional peak is the moment of ownership, the journey must build towards that milestone with rituals, celebration and genuine care.

banking.label: Banking & Financial Services
banking.description: Customers navigating trust, complexity and long-term financial wellbeing across retail, private and business banking.

archetypes.name: The Cautious Planner
archetypes.description: I am risk-averse by nature and see my bank as a guardian of my future, not a growth engine. I move slowly, ask many questions, and would rather miss an opportunity than take an uncertain risk. Every unexplained charge, every changed term and every unreturned call erodes trust that took years to build. I don't want to be sold to ‚Äî I want to be looked after.
archetypes.goals: I want financial stability above all else ‚Äî a growing savings buffer, no surprises, and the confidence that my family is protected if something goes wrong. Recognition matters less to me than certainty. I measure success by how well I sleep, not how fast my portfolio grows.
archetypes.needs: I need simple, transparent products with no hidden conditions. I research slowly, compare cautiously, and need every fee and term explained without jargon. I respond well to proactive communication ‚Äî being told about changes before they affect me, not after. I am deeply loyal to brands that never make me feel foolish for asking questions.
archetypes.touchpoints: I prefer branch and phone for anything important ‚Äî digital channels feel too impersonal when the stakes are real. I use the app for checking balances but would never set up a new product through it alone. Trusted advisors and face-to-face meetings are where I actually make decisions.
expectations: Proactive communication on changes
Plain-language explanations
No hidden fees
Consistent advisor contact
barriers: Financial jargon
Unexplained charges
Frequent product changes
Being transferred between teams
solution_principles: Because they need certainty above growth, every product must be explained in plain language with no assumed financial literacy.
Because trust is built slowly and lost instantly, proactive communication must replace reactive resolution at every touchpoint.
Because human contact is non-negotiable for high-stakes decisions, digital channels must always offer a frictionless path to a real person.

archetypes.name: The Digital Native
archetypes.description: I am app-first and branch-never. Banking should be invisible infrastructure ‚Äî frictionless, instant and entirely self-serve. I don't want a relationship with my bank; I want a platform that gets out of my way. The moment I have to call someone, visit somewhere or wait for anything, I start looking for an alternative.
archetypes.goals: I want my financial life to run itself ‚Äî automated savings, instant payments, real-time spending visibility, and smart nudges that keep me on track without requiring my attention. I want zero fees for the things I do every day and a product that rewards me for being digitally capable.
archetypes.needs: I need a mobile-first experience that is genuinely better than a spreadsheet. I respond to personalised insights, spend analytics, and instant notifications. I research entirely online ‚Äî YouTube reviews, Reddit communities, influencer comparisons. Onboarding must be under five minutes. I will switch the moment friction exceeds tolerance.
archetypes.touchpoints: The app is everything. I use comparison sites and fintech review communities to discover products. Social media ‚Äî specifically YouTube and TikTok ‚Äî shapes my perception of financial brands. I will engage with a chatbot willingly if it resolves things instantly. Email feels old. A letter is an insult.
expectations: Sub-5 minute onboarding
Real-time notifications
Instant transfers
Zero-fee everyday banking
barriers: Paper forms or branch visits
Slow verification processes
Outdated mobile interfaces
Opaque fee structures
solution_principles: Because friction is the enemy and speed is the product, every process must be completable within the app in under three steps.
Because discovery happens through peers and platforms, the brand must be present and credible in digital communities before it speaks to individuals.
Because switching is effortless, retention must be built through personalised value ‚Äî not contracts, not inertia.

archetypes.name: The Wealth Builder
archetypes.latin: Crescit Eundo (It Grows as It Goes)
archetypes.description: I am financially literate, ambitious and actively growing a portfolio. I see my bank as a tool ‚Äî useful if sharp, replaced if blunt. I compare rates, structures and products obsessively and I am not impressed by heritage or branch counts. I need best-in-class products backed by genuine expertise. I will not be talked down to and I will not pay for advice I could find free online.
archetypes.goals: I want meaningful capital growth, tax-efficient structures and access to investment products that match my risk appetite and horizon. I want my bank to help me pay less tax legally, grow assets intelligently and access opportunities before they become mainstream. I measure success in net worth trajectory, not current balance.
archetypes.needs: I need access to wealth advisory that goes beyond standard retail products ‚Äî ISAs, SIPPs, offshore structures, alternative investments. I research independently first and come to advisors for execution and edge, not education. I respond to data, market insight and genuine portfolio personalisation. I compare annually and switch without sentiment.
archetypes.touchpoints: Financial press, investment platforms and wealth advisory networks are my primary sources. I use the app for monitoring but make decisions in direct conversations with senior advisors. LinkedIn shapes my perception of institutions. I attend investment briefings and market events when the quality justifies it.
expectations: Senior advisor access
Proactive market insights
Product sophistication
Confidential and discreet service
barriers: Generic retail product offering
Junior or uninformed advisors
Slow execution
Lack of investment breadth
solution_principles: Because they arrive informed and expect to be met at their level, every advisor interaction must add value beyond what research alone can provide.
Because they compare relentlessly, the product proposition must be genuinely competitive ‚Äî not just positioned as such.
Because loyalty follows performance, proactive portfolio communication must happen before the client asks, never after.

archetypes.name: The Business Owner
archetypes.description: I run a business and my personal and professional finances are permanently blurred. I am time-poor, constantly context-switching and deeply frustrated by banking systems designed for either retail customers or large corporates ‚Äî never for businesses like mine. I need a bank that understands that my cash flow is not predictable and my needs are not standard. When things go wrong financially, I need a call returned the same day.
archetypes.goals: I want a business bank that functions as a financial partner ‚Äî one that understands my sector, anticipates my seasonal needs and can move quickly when an opportunity or a crisis demands it. I want my personal and business finances managed with minimum friction between them, and I want access to credit that reflects my business reality, not just a credit score.
archetypes.needs: I need responsive relationship management, fast credit decisions and accounting integrations that save me hours every month. I research through peer networks ‚Äî other business owners are my most trusted source. I need clear visibility of cash flow, payroll and tax obligations in a single place. I will pay more for a bank that genuinely reduces my administrative burden.
archetypes.touchpoints: Peer referrals and local business networks are how I discovered my bank. I use online banking and accounting integrations daily. I need a named relationship manager I can call ‚Äî not a call centre rotation. LinkedIn and industry events shape my perception of business banking brands.
expectations: Named relationship manager
Same-day response to urgent queries
Accounting software integration
Fast credit decisions
barriers: Generic SME products
Call centre routing
Slow credit processes
Lack of sector understanding
solution_principles: Because their time is the scarcest resource, every banking process must be completable with minimum steps and maximum automation.
Because a credit decision delayed is an opportunity missed, speed of response must be treated as a competitive product feature, not a service metric.
Because peer referral drives acquisition, the experience must be consistently good enough to be talked about in the business owner's network.

archetypes.name: The Global Nomad
archetypes.description: I am internationally mobile ‚Äî managing income, assets and obligations across multiple countries simultaneously. My financial life doesn't fit neatly into any one jurisdiction's banking model, and most banks treat cross-border behaviour as suspicious rather than normal. I need a bank that views my mobility as an asset, not a compliance problem. Discretion, speed of international transfers, and multi-currency capability are my baseline.
archetypes.goals: I want seamless global banking ‚Äî the ability to hold, convert and transfer multiple currencies without punitive fees or suspicious transaction flags. I want my bank to understand that my tax situation is complex by design, not by intention, and to provide the advisory support to navigate it correctly across jurisdictions.
archetypes.needs: I need multi-currency accounts, international transfer networks and compliance support for multiple tax residencies. I cannot visit a branch ‚Äî everything must work remotely, across time zones. I research through expat communities, international finance forums and global mobility platforms. I switch when a bank makes international life harder instead of easier.
archetypes.touchpoints: Expat forums, international relocation communities and global mobility platforms are my discovery channels. I use digital banking exclusively ‚Äî app and online. Video calls replace in-person meetings. I value bank representatives who understand international compliance, not just domestic products.
expectations: Multi-currency accounts
Zero international transfer friction
Remote-first service
Cross-border compliance support
barriers: Suspicious transaction flags
Branch visit requirements
Single-currency limitations
Jurisdiction knowledge gaps
triggers: New income stream in different currency
solution_principles: Because their geography is permanently variable, the entire banking relationship must function flawlessly without a branch, a physical meeting or a domestic phone number.
Because cross-border complexity is their daily reality, the bank must be a guide through compliance ‚Äî not a gatekeeper that treats mobility as risk.
Because they cannot afford frozen accounts or failed transfers, reliability and transparency of international processes must be the primary product promise.

archetypes.name: The Debt Escaper
archetypes.description: I am managing debt ‚Äî sometimes overwhelmed by it, sometimes working systematically to eliminate it. I feel judged by financial institutions and I approach banking interactions with a degree of shame and anxiety that I rarely disclose. I need non-judgmental support, clear repayment tools and products that help me build financial health, not ones that profit from my vulnerability. A single empathetic interaction can change my relationship with money.
archetypes.goals: I want to get out of debt with a clear plan and a bank that actively supports my progress rather than extracting maximum interest. I want to rebuild my credit rating, access better products as I improve, and eventually reach a point where money feels like a tool rather than a source of stress. Financial health ‚Äî not wealth ‚Äî is my definition of success.
archetypes.needs: I need honest budgeting tools, debt consolidation clarity and a repayment plan that is achievable rather than aspirational. I respond to positive reinforcement ‚Äî milestones, progress indicators, small wins. I am deeply sensitive to being sold products I don't need. I need to trust that my bank is on my side, not optimising for my balance sheet.
archetypes.touchpoints: I research through financial wellbeing communities, debt advice forums and money management apps. I am cautious with official banking channels due to past negative experiences. I respond well to digital self-serve tools that let me manage and track without human judgment. Debt advice charities have often been more helpful than banks.
expectations: Non-judgmental support
Clear repayment tools
Honest budgeting features
Progress milestones
barriers: Shame and stigma
Products designed to extend debt
Lack of empathetic communication
Complex financial language
solution_principles: Because shame is the primary barrier to engagement, every communication must be designed to remove judgment and replace it with practical, non-conditional support.
Because progress ‚Äî however small ‚Äî rebuilds confidence, the product experience must celebrate milestones and make the path forward visible at all times.
Because vulnerability makes people sensitive to exploitation, the brand must never cross-sell or upsell during a debt management journey ‚Äî trust must be earned before products are offered.

archetypes.name: The Retirement Nearing
archetypes.description: I have worked for decades and I am now within sight of retirement ‚Äî close enough to feel the urgency of getting the financial transition right. I have accumulated assets but I am not entirely sure they are structured optimally. I am increasingly aware of mortality, legacy and the difference between what I have and what I need. I want my bank to help me cross the finish line with everything in order.
archetypes.goals: I want a retirement income that sustains my lifestyle without eroding my capital too quickly, and a legacy plan that reflects my values and protects the people I care about. I want clarity above all ‚Äî to understand exactly what I have, what I will have, and what my family will receive. I want to spend the next chapter enjoying my life, not managing spreadsheets.
archetypes.needs: I need pension consolidation, drawdown planning, inheritance tax structuring and estate planning support. I research through trusted financial advisors and long-established publications. I am not digitally avoidant but I prefer human advisory for decisions of this significance. I need a bank that treats this life stage with the gravity it deserves.
archetypes.touchpoints: Financial advisors, retirement planning publications and peer conversations are my primary channels. I use online banking for day-to-day monitoring but make significant decisions in face-to-face meetings. I am increasingly alert to fraud ‚Äî any unsolicited contact is treated with suspicion. I am deeply loyal to advisors who have been honest with me over time.
expectations: Dedicated retirement advisor
Clear legacy planning tools
Pension consolidation support
Estate planning guidance
barriers: Complexity of pension landscape
Fear of fraud
Unclear drawdown implications
Feeling like a number not a person
solution_principles: Because the stakes of getting retirement wrong are irreversible, the experience must make complexity feel managed ‚Äî not minimised ‚Äî through genuine expertise and proactive guidance.
Because legacy is as important as lifestyle, estate and inheritance planning must be treated as a core product, not an afterthought sold by a different team.
Because trust in this life stage is built on decades, not campaigns, the advisor relationship must be protected, consistent and never handed over without consent.

archetypes.name: The Young Aspirant
archetypes.latin: Dum Spiro Spero (While I Breathe I Hope)
archetypes.description: I am in my twenties, starting my financial life with energy but limited knowledge. I have student debt, a first salary, and enormous financial ambitions that exceed my current means. I am learning about money in real time ‚Äî through social media, through mistakes, through friends. I want a bank that feels like it was designed for me, not inherited from my parents' generation.
archetypes.goals: I want to save for my first home, eliminate student debt and build an investment habit before I'm thirty. I want my bank to help me understand money ‚Äî not to exploit my inexperience. I want to feel like I am getting ahead, even if progress is slow. Recognition of my ambition, not just my current balance, matters enormously.
archetypes.needs: I need budgeting tools, automated savings features, accessible investment products and financial education baked into the app experience. I research through TikTok, YouTube finance creators and peer groups. I am open to gamified experiences, goal-setting and milestone rewards. I will leave a bank that makes me feel small for not having more.
archetypes.touchpoints: Social media ‚Äî particularly short-form video ‚Äî is where financial literacy is happening for my generation. I discovered my current account through a peer recommendation or influencer review. The app is my primary interface. I use comparison sites annually. I attend no branch, read no letters and find phone banking baffling.
expectations: Financial education in-app
Automated savings tools
First investment access
Goal-based banking features
barriers: Minimum balance requirements
Inaccessible investment products
Feeling talked down to
Irrelevant product offers
solution_principles: Because financial literacy is being built in real time, the product experience must educate without condescending ‚Äî making every feature a moment of understanding, not just a function.
Because aspiration outpaces current means, the brand must recognise the trajectory, not just the balance ‚Äî and design products for who they are becoming.
Because their loyalty is shaped entirely by peer conversation and digital experience, the product must be genuinely worth recommending ‚Äî not just adequate.

hospitality.label: Hospitality & Tourism
hospitality.description: Travellers and guests seeking escape, experience and emotional connection across hotels, airlines, resorts and destination travel.

archetypes.name: The Experience Curator
archetypes.latin: Vita Brevis Ars Longa (Life is Short, Art is Long)
archetypes.description: I travel for stories, not convenience. I research obsessively ‚Äî not to eliminate risk but to maximise depth. I want to eat where locals eat, sleep somewhere with a soul, and return with experiences that cannot be packaged or replicated. I distrust anything described as a tourist attraction and I am deeply allergic to the generic. My itinerary is hand-built, not booked through a package.
archetypes.goals: I want to return from every trip with something that changed how I see the world ‚Äî a conversation, a meal, a neighbourhood, a moment of unexpected beauty. I measure a trip not by what I saw but by what I felt. I want to discover places before they are discovered, and I want the brands I travel with to make that possible rather than impossible.
archetypes.needs: I need rich local intelligence ‚Äî neighbourhood guides, off-menu recommendations, cultural context, seasonal nuance. I research through travel journals, curated blogs, local Instagram accounts and slow-travel communities. I need accommodation that has its own character and staff who genuinely know their city. I will pay a premium for authenticity and walk away from anything that feels manufactured.
archetypes.touchpoints: Independent travel blogs, long-form journalism and community forums like Reddit travel communities are my primary research channels. I book direct where possible to avoid losing the human thread. I discover new properties through word of mouth and considered editorial ‚Äî not paid placement. Instagram is a source of inspiration, not a booking engine.
expectations: Genuine local knowledge from staff
Character and soul in the property
No generic tourist packaging
Pre-arrival local intelligence
barriers: Over-standardised chain experience
Generic city guides
Lack of local staff knowledge
Package-tour feel
solution_principles: Because authenticity is the product and manufactured experiences are actively repellent, the brand must invest in genuine local knowledge and make it generously available before, during and after the stay.
Because discovery is the emotional peak, the experience must create moments of unexpected delight rather than a flawlessly executed script.
Because they travel to be changed, every touchpoint must honour the intelligence of the traveller and resist the temptation to simplify what is beautifully complex.

archetypes.name: The Family Organiser
archetypes.description: I carry the invisible weight of making everyone happy simultaneously. A holiday is not a holiday for me ‚Äî it is a logistics project with emotional consequences. I research obsessively to eliminate risk: the wrong hotel room, the inaccessible beach, the restaurant with nothing on the menu for a fussy seven-year-old. If it goes wrong, I hear about it. If it goes right, everyone else gets the credit.
archetypes.goals: I want a trip where every family member ‚Äî from toddler to teenager to grandparent ‚Äî has their needs met without me having to fight for every accommodation. I want predictability, flexibility, and the confidence that what I booked is what we will experience. I want to actually relax at some point on the holiday I have spent months planning.
archetypes.needs: I need family-specific information that goes beyond a 'family room' checkbox ‚Äî connecting rooms, pool depth, kids' club age ranges, proximity to medical facilities. I research across multiple platforms and I am highly sensitive to discrepancies between what is shown and what exists. I need flexible cancellation because family life is unpredictable. I am deeply loyal to brands that make family travel easier, not just possible.
archetypes.touchpoints: Parenting communities, family travel blogs and peer recommendations from trusted friends are my primary discovery channels. I use OTA platforms for comparison but often book direct once trust is established. I read every review mentioning children. I book far in advance and confirm multiple times. WhatsApp groups with family members are part of my coordination layer.
expectations: Accurate family-specific property information
Flexible cancellation
Kids' facilities clearly detailed
Connecting rooms availability
barriers: Misleading photography or descriptions
Rigid booking policies
Poor on-site children's facilities
Lack of age-appropriate activities
solution_principles: Because the cost of a bad family holiday is measured in months of planning wasted and family disappointment, the accuracy and completeness of family-specific information must be treated as the primary product promise.
Because flexibility is the most valued feature when children are involved, cancellation, modification and rebooking policies must be designed around family realities, not revenue protection.

Because they are the invisible architect of everyone else's good time, the brand must acknowledge and celebrate the organiser ‚Äî not just the family ‚Äî and make their experience of the journey as rewarding as the destination.

archetypes.name: The Luxury Escapist
archetypes.description: I travel to decompress from a life that demands my constant attention. I am not here for discovery or adventure ‚Äî I am here for the complete suspension of responsibility. I want everything handled before I arrive, everything anticipated while I am there, and nothing required of me beyond presence. I have high standards because I have worked extremely hard, and a service failure during my rare time off is not a minor inconvenience ‚Äî it is a profound disappointment.
archetypes.goals: I want to be entirely looked after ‚Äî physically, emotionally, logistically. I want to arrive somewhere beautiful and not make a single decision that I don't choose to make. I want the property to know my preferences before I state them and to solve problems before I notice them. The measure of a great stay is leaving feeling genuinely restored.
archetypes.needs: I need pre-arrival concierge communication that feels personal, not templated. I need my preferences remembered and acted upon without being asked twice. I respond to anticipatory service ‚Äî the refilled glass, the adjusted room temperature, the restaurant reservation for the time I typically dine. I research through luxury travel specialists, trusted publications and personal network recommendations.
archetypes.touchpoints: Luxury travel consultants, private members' clubs and high-end editorial are my discovery channels. Word of mouth within my network carries the greatest weight ‚Äî a personal recommendation from a peer is worth more than any campaign. I engage with the property directly once booked and expect a single point of contact who knows my file.
expectations: Pre-arrival preference capture
Anticipatory service throughout
Single dedicated contact
Zero visible effort on their part
barriers: Templated pre-arrival communication
Preferences not remembered between stays
Visible operational inefficiency
Having to ask for anything twice
solution_principles: Because the value proposition is the complete suspension of effort, the experience must eliminate every moment where a guest has to ask, wait or think about something operational.
Because anticipatory service is the luxury differentiator, preference data must be captured, acted upon and never repeated as a question ‚Äî memory is a fundamental product feature.
Because a single failure in a flawless stay is disproportionately remembered, service recovery must be immediate, generous and delivered without the guest having to escalate.

archetypes.name: The Points Strategist
archetypes.latin: Optimum ex Omnibus (The Best from Everything)
archetypes.description: I have turned loyalty programmes into a second income stream. I understand redemption rates, transfer ratios, earning multipliers and blackout windows better than most airline employees. I choose hotels, airlines and credit cards based on their programme mechanics as much as their product quality. My loyalty is entirely rational ‚Äî I follow the points, not the brand, and I am deeply fluent in the language of tier status and benefit access.
archetypes.goals: I want maximum points per pound spent, tier status that delivers meaningful upgrades and access, and redemptions that return genuine value ‚Äî not the base rates that programmes quietly offer as defaults. I want programmes that reward engagement intelligently and treat high-earning members with the recognition their spend justifies.
archetypes.needs: I need real-time points visibility, clear tier progress tracking, and upgrade availability that is actually available. I research programme mechanics obsessively ‚Äî through points communities, comparison tools and airline forums. I am deeply frustrated by programme devaluations and respond to them publicly. I engage most when there is a clear path to the next tier milestone.
archetypes.touchpoints: Loyalty programme communities, points and miles blogs, credit card comparison platforms and airline status forums are my primary channels. I follow programme change announcements with the attention others give to financial news. I engage directly with the programme app more than the product brand. Partner relationships and earning opportunities drive booking decisions as much as price.
expectations: Real-time points balance accuracy
Transparent tier progression
Meaningful upgrade availability
Consistent partner earning
barriers: Programme devaluations without notice
Upgrade availability that doesn't exist
Points expiry without warning
Poor redemption value at base rates
solution_principles: Because programme integrity is the primary loyalty driver, any devaluation, restriction or change must be communicated proactively and justified honestly ‚Äî not buried in terms and conditions.
Because they measure value in mathematical precision, the programme must deliver redemption experiences that genuinely exceed base expectations, not just technically fulfil the promise.
Because their advocacy amplifies brand perception in engaged communities, treating top-tier members with consistent and visible recognition is not a cost ‚Äî it is a marketing strategy.

archetypes.name: The Digital Nomad
archetypes.latin: Nusquam Est Qui Ubique Est (Nowhere is Everywhere)
archetypes.description: I have dissolved the line between work and travel so completely that I'm not sure it ever existed for me. I evaluate destinations by connectivity and co-working infrastructure as much as culture. I need my accommodation to understand that my laptop is as important as my passport, and that a sunset means nothing if the WiFi dropped at 4pm during a client call. I am loyal to brands that genuinely accommodate how I actually live.
archetypes.goals: I want to build a life that is simultaneously productive and exploratory ‚Äî to do my best work from places that inspire me and to explore those places without sacrificing professional reliability. I want accommodation brands that see long-stay guests as a relationship to invest in, not a rate to discount. I want a community of like-minded people in every city I land in.
archetypes.needs: I need verified, fast WiFi ‚Äî not the number the hotel claims, but the actual experience at 10am on a Tuesday. I need ergonomic workspace, reliable power, accessible co-working options, and a community of people doing something similar. I research through nomad communities, city-specific Slack groups and long-stay accommodation platforms. I book for weeks or months at a time when I find the right base.
archetypes.touchpoints: Digital nomad forums, city-specific remote work communities, co-living platform reviews and long-stay booking platforms are my discovery channels. Social media ‚Äî particularly Instagram and Twitter ‚Äî is where I build community in new cities. I am deeply loyal to properties that have invested in genuinely understanding my lifestyle, not just labelling a corner 'the co-working space'.
expectations: Verified fast WiFi
Ergonomic workspace
Long-stay flexibility
Like-minded community access
barriers: Overstated WiFi speeds
Short-stay-only pricing
Lack of co-working investment
Isolation in accommodation
triggers: New visa or country opening up
solution_principles: Because connectivity is as fundamental as a bed, WiFi must be treated as infrastructure ‚Äî tested, guaranteed and communicated with the same confidence as room type.
Because long-stay guests are a relationship not a transaction, pricing, flexibility and community access must reward duration rather than penalising it.
Because community is a core product need, the property must actively facilitate connections between guests rather than leaving serendipity to chance.

archetypes.name: The Wellness Pilgrim
archetypes.latin: Sana Corpus, Sana Mentem (Heal the Body, Heal the Mind)
archetypes.description: I travel with deliberate healing intent. The destination is a vehicle for transformation ‚Äî physical, emotional, spiritual. I am not interested in sightseeing; I am interested in returning home measurably better than I left. I invest significantly in wellness travel because I understand the compounding returns of genuine restoration. I am highly discerning and deeply disappointed by wellness experiences that are aesthetic rather than substantive.
archetypes.goals: I want to leave a trip feeling physically reset, emotionally lighter and mentally clear. I want experiences that go beyond surface-level spa treatments ‚Äî retreats that offer genuine programmes, expert practitioners, nutritional intelligence, and the space to be genuinely still. I want my investment to produce a lasting result, not a temporary relaxation.
archetypes.needs: I need detailed programme content, practitioner credentials, dietary philosophy and daily structure before I commit. I research through wellness travel specialists, retreat review communities and health-focused editorial. I am not price-sensitive but I am value-sensitive ‚Äî a high price is acceptable, an empty promise is not. I book far in advance and engage deeply with pre-arrival preparation guidance.
archetypes.touchpoints: Wellness travel platforms, specialist retreat booking sites, health and longevity publications and practitioner recommendations are my discovery channels. I engage with the property in depth before booking ‚Äî asking detailed questions about methodology, ingredients and outcomes. Peer testimonials from people with similar health goals carry the most weight.
expectations: Detailed programme content pre-booking
Credentialled practitioners
Nutritional transparency
Measurable outcomes framework
barriers: Aesthetic wellness with no substance
Uncredentialled staff
Vague programme descriptions
Wellness as an add-on not a core proposition
solution_principles: Because wellness intent requires substantive delivery, every programme claim must be backed by visible expertise, credentialled practitioners and clearly communicated methodology.

Because transformation begins before arrival, the pre-trip experience must be as carefully designed as the retreat itself ‚Äî with preparation guidance that signals what the programme takes seriously.
Because a superficial wellness experience is a more acute disappointment than a standard hotel shortfall, the brand must under-promise on aesthetics and over-deliver on outcomes.

archetypes.name: The Budget Adventurer
archetypes.latin: Longe Ire, Parce Impendere (Go Far, Spend Little)
archetypes.description: I measure a great trip in experiences per pound, not stars per night. I am not slumming it ‚Äî I am optimising. I have learned that the best experiences in travel are rarely the most expensive ones and I have built the research skills to find them. I am flexible, resourceful and entirely unbothered by the absence of a minibar. What I cannot tolerate is being overcharged for something I didn't choose, or being made to feel lesser for caring about price.
archetypes.goals: I want to go further, stay longer and see more than my budget should theoretically allow. I want brands that respect intelligent frugality ‚Äî not ones that hide fees, charge for basics or make the economy tier a punishment. I want the freedom that comes from spending less on accommodation and more on the moments that actually matter.
archetypes.needs: I need transparent all-in pricing with no hidden fees. I research extensively across comparison platforms, travel hacking communities and budget travel blogs. I am highly sensitive to surprise charges and cancellation penalties. I value flexible policies, honest facilities descriptions and accommodation that is genuinely clean and safe even if it is not luxurious. I am loyal to brands that respect my intelligence.
archetypes.touchpoints: Comparison platforms, budget travel communities, hostel review aggregators and travel hacking forums are my primary channels. Social media ‚Äî particularly YouTube travel vlogs ‚Äî shapes my destination choices. I book last-minute when possible to capture deals. I use price alert tools and set up notifications for fare drops. I am an active reviewer and share feedback publicly after every stay.
expectations: All-in transparent pricing
No hidden fees
Honest facilities description
Flexible cancellation
barriers: Hidden charges
Punitive cancellation terms
Facilities that don't match descriptions
Being made to feel lesser for price-consciousness
solution_principles: Because transparency is the non-negotiable baseline and hidden fees are an active betrayal, all-in pricing must be visible at the first moment of consideration ‚Äî not revealed at checkout.
Because frugality is intelligence not limitation, the brand must design the budget tier as a genuine product, not a stripped-back punishment that communicates low status.

Because they are active and influential reviewers, the experience at every price point must be consistently good enough to earn public praise ‚Äî a negative review from this archetype carries disproportionate weight.

archetypes.name: The Romantic Celebrant
archetypes.description: I am travelling for a moment, not just a trip. A honeymoon, a proposal, an anniversary, a milestone birthday ‚Äî the occasion gives the travel its meaning and makes every detail matter more than it otherwise would. I am not necessarily a luxury traveller in ordinary life, but for this trip I am willing to invest significantly because the memory must be commensurate with the occasion. A failure here is not a bad stay ‚Äî it is a ruined milestone.
archetypes.goals: I want the trip to produce a memory that we talk about for decades. I want the place to feel like it was chosen for us specifically, not for everyone. I want small gestures that acknowledge why we are there ‚Äî without being intrusive or performative. I want to leave having created something that belongs entirely to us.
archetypes.needs: I need a brand that takes occasion seriously ‚Äî that asks the right questions before arrival, prepares thoughtful gestures without being asked, and understands that a surprise anniversary cake is only romantic if it is actually surprising and actually good. I research through honeymoon specialist platforms, couples travel communities and editorial focused on romantic destinations.
archetypes.touchpoints: Honeymoon and romantic travel specialists, couples travel communities, wedding planning platforms and editorial on romantic destinations are my discovery channels. Peer recommendations from recently married couples carry enormous weight. I am willing to engage extensively with a property before arrival if the communication feels personal ‚Äî I will disengage immediately if it feels automated.
expectations: Occasion acknowledged without prompting
Personalised touches on arrival
Privacy and intimacy by design
Memorable gestures that feel genuine
barriers: Generic welcome regardless of occasion
Automated pre-arrival communication
Staff unawareness of the occasion
Gestures that feel performative or scripted
triggers: Making up for a previous trip that fell short
solution_principles: Because the occasion amplifies every detail into a memory, the brand must actively gather occasion context and use it to personalise the experience ‚Äî not as a upsell, but as an act of care.
Because a missed gesture on a milestone trip is remembered forever, occasion awareness must be embedded in operations, not left to the goodwill of individual staff.
Because the emotional stakes make them both the most loyal advocates and the most vocal critics, the experience must earn the story they will tell for the rest of their lives.

healthcare.label: Healthcare & Wellness
healthcare.description: Patients, caregivers and wellness seekers navigating vulnerability, complexity and trust across hospitals, clinics, insurers and wellness providers.

archetypes.name: The Vigilant Advocate
archetypes.description: I arrive at every healthcare interaction having already done substantial research. I am proactive, informed and deeply involved ‚Äî often navigating the system on behalf of a family member as much as myself. I ask difficult questions not to be difficult, but because I understand that the quality of my questions directly affects the quality of my care. I expect genuine engagement from providers, not managed reassurance. I am the patient who reads the studies.
archetypes.goals: I want to be a genuine partner in my healthcare decisions ‚Äî not a passive recipient of instructions. I want providers who welcome my research, correct it when it is wrong, and build on it when it is right. I want clarity on diagnosis, options, risks and outcomes in enough depth to make truly informed choices. I measure success by understanding, not just by outcome.
archetypes.needs: I need time ‚Äî enough of it that a conversation can happen. I need providers who are not threatened by an informed patient. I need access to my records, test results and treatment notes. I research through peer-reviewed literature, specialist communities and patient networks. I am deeply frustrated by being managed rather than engaged and by information withheld under the guise of simplification.
archetypes.touchpoints: Patient advocacy networks, condition-specific communities, specialist medical publications and direct provider communication are my primary channels. I use patient portals extensively and am frustrated when they don't contain everything I need. I prepare written questions for appointments. I compare providers on their willingness to engage, not just their clinical ratings.
expectations: Time for genuine consultation
Access to full medical records
Providers who engage with research
Honest communication about uncertainty
barriers: Rushed appointments
Information withheld for simplicity
Providers threatened by informed patients
Fragmented care records
solution_principles: Because an informed patient improves outcomes, every touchpoint must treat patient knowledge as an asset and create space for genuine clinical dialogue rather than managed reassurance.
Because access to information is experienced as respect, patient portals, records and test results must be complete, timely and written for the patient ‚Äî not for the clinician.

Because care fragmentation is their greatest frustration, continuity of information across every provider in the care journey must be treated as a clinical priority, not an administrative convenience.

archetypes.name: The Anxious Patient
archetypes.description: I avoid healthcare until avoidance is no longer possible. The fear of a bad diagnosis is more powerful than the fear of staying unwell ‚Äî I know this is irrational and it does not help. Once I am finally in the system, every step carries disproportionate dread: the waiting room, the letter, the phone call that might not be good news. I need extraordinary empathy in every moment. Calm, clear and human communication is not a nice-to-have for me ‚Äî it is the difference between engaging and disappearing.
archetypes.goals: I want to get through the healthcare process without it making my anxiety worse. I want to feel safe, seen and not judged for having taken this long to come forward. I want information delivered in a way that doesn't spiral me into catastrophic thinking. I want someone to be human with me ‚Äî not clinical, not rushed, not distant.
archetypes.needs: I need communication that is clear without being alarming, empathetic without being patronising. I need waiting times communicated honestly because silence is where my anxiety lives. I need the option to be accompanied and for that companion to be welcomed, not tolerated. I research through symptom checkers and health anxiety communities ‚Äî often making my anxiety worse before I get better information.
archetypes.touchpoints: I typically first engage through online symptom research ‚Äî often a spiral. I arrive at a GP reluctantly and often after weeks of delay. I use the NHS app or patient portal for results with dread. Letters feel formal and threatening regardless of content. A phone call with an unknown number from a medical practice causes acute anxiety before I answer it.
expectations: Warm, non-clinical first contact
Honest wait time communication
No judgment for delayed presentation
Companion welcomed at appointments
barriers: Unexplained waiting
Cold or rushed communication
Letters with no context
Phone calls from unknown numbers with no voicemail
drivers: Being seen as a person not a case
triggers: Online research that finally becomes too alarming to ignore
solution_principles: Because the anxiety begins before the appointment and peaks in silence, every communication gap must be filled with calm, honest information ‚Äî waiting room time, result timelines, next steps ‚Äî before the patient has to ask.

Because the presenting barrier is fear not reluctance, the first contact experience must be designed to reduce anxiety rather than efficiently process an appointment ‚Äî tone is clinical infrastructure.
Because one empathetic interaction can reverse years of avoidance, every staff member must be trained to recognise and respond to anxiety presentations ‚Äî this is as important as clinical protocol.

archetypes.name: The Wellness Optimiser
archetypes.latin: Mens Sana in Corpore Sano (A Healthy Mind in a Healthy Body)
archetypes.description: I treat my health as a performance system to be optimised, not a problem to be managed when it breaks. I track, measure and improve continuously ‚Äî sleep quality, HRV, VO2 max, gut microbiome, cognitive function. I engage with healthcare providers as coaches in my optimisation programme, not authorities to be deferred to when I am ill. Prevention is my primary healthcare relationship and I invest substantially in it.
archetypes.goals: I want to reach my eighties in the physical condition of a healthy forty-year-old. I want personalised health intelligence ‚Äî not generic guidelines designed for the median population. I want early warning signals before they become problems, and a healthcare relationship that rewards proactive engagement rather than only activating in crisis.
archetypes.needs: I need providers who engage seriously with longevity science, biomarker testing, personalised nutrition and functional medicine. I research through health optimisation podcasts, longevity literature and practitioner networks. I use wearables and health apps as primary data sources and I want my providers to engage with that data rather than dismiss it. I am willing to pay significantly for genuinely personalised preventive care.
archetypes.touchpoints: Health optimisation podcasts, longevity science publications, specialist functional medicine practitioners and premium health technology platforms are my primary channels. I use wearables constantly ‚Äî the data they produce is the first thing I look at in the morning. I am an early adopter of health technology and share my experiences in peer communities.
expectations: Engagement with wearable and biomarker data
Personalised rather than population-average advice
Preventive protocol access
Longevity-literate practitioners
barriers: Dismissal of self-tracked data
Generic population-average guidelines
Reactive rather than preventive orientation
Lack of functional medicine access
solution_principles: Because prevention is the primary product, the care model must be structured around proactive health maintenance rather than reactive illness management ‚Äî and priced accordingly.
Because self-tracked data is how they understand their body, providers must be willing and equipped to engage with wearable and app data as legitimate clinical input, not anecdotal noise.
Because they compare providers on scientific rigour, every recommendation must be evidence-based and personalised ‚Äî generic population guidelines will be challenged and lose credibility.

archetypes.name: The Dependent Caregiver
archetypes.description: I navigate the healthcare system primarily on behalf of someone I love ‚Äî a parent, a partner, a child. My own needs are permanently secondary and I am largely invisible to the system that relies on me to make it work. I am exhausted, often under-informed because information is given to the patient not to me, and deeply frustrated by a system that treats the person I care for as an individual case rather than as someone embedded in a family that is also affected.
archetypes.goals: I want the system to acknowledge that I exist and that I matter to the care outcome. I want to be included in communication, informed about what to expect at home, and supported with the practical reality of providing care. I want a healthcare system that sees care as a team sport, and that treats me as an essential member of that team.
archetypes.needs: I need proactive information sharing ‚Äî not just what is happening but what I should watch for, how to manage symptoms at home, and when to seek further help. I need the system to make it easy for me to communicate on behalf of the person in my care. I research through caregiver support communities, condition-specific forums and charity resources. I am frequently the one who spots the thing the clinical team missed.
archetypes.touchpoints: Caregiver support organisations, condition-specific family networks and charity helplines are where I find the information the healthcare system does not provide. I engage with the system through appointments I accompany, phone calls I make on behalf of others and patient portals I help manage. Discharge paperwork is critical ‚Äî it is the moment when responsibility passes to me.
expectations: Inclusion in care communication
Home management guidance on discharge
Recognition of caregiver burden
Clear escalation pathways
barriers: Information given only to patient
Discharge without adequate home guidance
System treating care as purely individual
Being ignored in clinical conversations
drivers: Care quality for their loved one
solution_principles: Because the caregiver is an unpaid clinical extension of the healthcare system, discharge and home management information must be designed for the carer's reality ‚Äî not the patient's idealised compliance.
Because exclusion from communication is experienced as disrespect, consent-based information sharing with designated caregivers must be the default, not an exception requiring administrative effort.
Because caregiver burnout directly harms patient outcomes, every care pathway must include explicit acknowledgment and practical support for the people providing care at home.

archetypes.name: The Chronic Navigator
archetypes.latin: Per Diem, Per Vitam (Day by Day, For Life)
archetypes.description: I have been living with a chronic condition for long enough that I know more about managing it than most of the generalists I see. My relationship with healthcare is permanent ‚Äî not episodic. I am not frightened of my condition; I am frustrated by a system designed for acute care that has never learned to serve people who will always be there. I need consistency, continuity and a care team that remembers who I am without me having to re-explain myself every visit.
archetypes.goals: I want a healthcare relationship that evolves with me as my condition changes ‚Äî not a series of disconnected appointments where I start from scratch each time. I want my care team to know my history, my preferences and my lifestyle. I want shared decision-making on treatment adjustments and the ability to self-manage confidently within agreed parameters. I want my condition to take up the smallest possible amount of my life.
archetypes.needs: I need continuity of care ‚Äî the same GP, the same specialist, or at minimum a shared care record that means I am not the only thread connecting my care. I need fast access for acute flare-ups without going through emergency routes designed for people without established care relationships. I research through condition-specific communities, patient advocacy groups and clinical trial databases. I am often the most informed person in the room about my own condition.
archetypes.touchpoints: Condition-specific patient communities, chronic illness advocacy networks, specialist forums and research publications are my primary channels alongside direct healthcare engagement. I use wearables and symptom tracking apps as management tools. I attend specialist clinics regularly and am deeply loyal to clinicians who offer genuine continuity. A change of consultant without consultation is a significant relationship break.
expectations: Care continuity and record completeness
Fast flare-up access pathways
Shared decision-making on adjustments
Self-management support within agreed limits
barriers: Re-explaining history at every appointment
Consultant changes without consultation
Acute system access for non-acute needs
Generic advice that ignores their management experience
solution_principles: Because continuity is the product for chronic care, the shared care record must be treated as the most important clinical document ‚Äî complete, accessible and never the patient's responsibility to maintain.
Because they know more about their condition than most generalists, clinical conversations must be collaborative ‚Äî the patient's lived expertise must be incorporated, not overridden.

Because the system was built for acute episodes not permanent relationships, fast-track access pathways for established chronic patients must exist and be proactively communicated ‚Äî emergency routes are not the answer.

archetypes.name: The Mental Health Seeker
archetypes.latin: Lux in Tenebris (Light in the Darkness)
archetypes.description: I am navigating mental health challenges ‚Äî sometimes for the first time, sometimes returning to familiar territory. The decision to seek help was not easy and the system has not always made it feel worthwhile. I carry stigma ‚Äî sometimes internalised, sometimes reflected by others ‚Äî and I am exquisitely sensitive to how I am received. I need to feel that seeking help was the right decision within the first interaction, or I may not come back.
archetypes.goals: I want to feel better ‚Äî not just functionally capable but genuinely well. I want a practitioner who sees me as a whole person and not a set of symptoms. I want a care journey that is consistent, not dependent on whoever happens to be available. I want to build tools and understanding, not just manage symptoms indefinitely. Progress matters ‚Äî however non-linear it may be.
archetypes.needs: I need to feel genuinely heard in the first session ‚Äî not assessed through a tick-box framework. I need consistency of practitioner ‚Äî therapeutic relationships are built on trust that cannot be transferred. I need flexible access between sessions: a message, a check-in, a resource ‚Äî not a three-week wait when I am struggling. I research carefully through community recommendation and am deeply influenced by peer experience.
archetypes.touchpoints: Mental health communities, peer recommendation, trusted GP referral and direct specialist booking platforms are my discovery channels. I engage with self-help content between sessions ‚Äî podcasts, apps and community forums. I am influenced significantly by how the first appointment is booked and what happens in the waiting room before I even meet the practitioner.
expectations: To be genuinely heard in first session
Consistent practitioner throughout
Between-session support access
Non-judgmental reception at every step
barriers: Tick-box assessment feeling
Practitioner changes mid-treatment
Three-week waits during acute periods
Stigma reflected in clinical tone or environment
drivers: Being seen as a whole person
mindset: Deeply responsive to how they are received
solution_principles: Because the decision to seek help is fragile and hard-won, the first interaction ‚Äî from booking to waiting room to first session ‚Äî must communicate safety, not efficiency.
Because therapeutic relationships cannot be transferred without damage, practitioner continuity must be treated as a clinical outcome measure, not an operational variable.
Because mental health deteriorates in gaps, between-session touchpoints ‚Äî however light ‚Äî must be designed into the care model rather than left to the patient to manage alone.

archetypes.name: The Reluctant Presenter
archetypes.description: I have not come to the doctor willingly. I am here because someone made me, because I finally ran out of rationalisations, or because something happened that made the risk of not coming worse than the risk of coming. I am not engaged, not informed and not particularly cooperative ‚Äî but this is not obstinacy. It is a combination of historical distrust, low health literacy and a genuine belief that the system is not built for people like me. One great interaction could change that.
archetypes.goals: Frankly, I want to get in, get whatever needs to happen done, and get out with as little disruption to my life as possible. In the best version of this, something the clinician says or does makes me feel that the visit was worthwhile ‚Äî that this was useful, that I am valued, that I should come back earlier next time. I am not unreachable; I am just not where the system expects me to be.
archetypes.needs: I need brevity without dismissiveness. I need the clinician to understand that my apparent indifference is a presentation, not my actual relationship with my own health. I need information given to me in a form that I can use ‚Äî not a leaflet, not a website, not a referral I will not follow up without a nudge. I am often more unwell than I present and I need the system to look beyond the surface.
archetypes.touchpoints: I rarely seek healthcare proactively. I typically arrive via a prompted route ‚Äî a partner's insistence, a workplace health screening, a pharmacy conversation, or a symptom that could no longer be ignored. I am most reachable through community health settings, pharmacy consultations and workplaces. Digital health engagement is low unless something is intuitive and immediately useful.
expectations: Brevity and respect for time
No judgment for delayed presentation
Actionable information in accessible form
A reason to come back
barriers: Perceived lack of relevance to their life
Historical distrust of healthcare
Complex information delivery
Feeling like a burden
solution_principles: Because their apparent disengagement masks genuine health need, every interaction must look beyond the presenting behaviour and create a moment of genuine human connection that makes returning feel worthwhile.
Because health literacy is low and leaflets are ineffective, every actionable instruction must be delivered verbally, briefly and with one clear next step ‚Äî complexity is the enemy of compliance.

Because the system rarely reaches them proactively, community health settings, pharmacy partnerships and workplace health programmes must be invested in as primary care access points for this archetype.

luxury_retail.label: Luxury Retail & Fashion
luxury_retail.description: High-value consumers driven by identity, exclusivity, craftsmanship and emotional reward across fashion, jewellery, watches, accessories and lifestyle.

archetypes.name: The Identity Collector
archetypes.latin: Habeo Ergo Sum (I Own Therefore I Am)
archetypes.description: I purchase luxury as a deliberate extension of self ‚Äî each piece is a carefully chosen statement about who I am and who I intend to be perceived as. Heritage, provenance and the craft narrative behind an object matter as much as the object itself. I do not collect things; I collect meaning. I would rather wait a year for the right piece than settle for what is available today. My relationship with a brand is biographical, not transactional.
archetypes.goals: I want a wardrobe and a collection that speak coherently about my values, my taste and my trajectory. I want pieces that appreciate ‚Äî financially and culturally. I want to be known by the brands I choose, and I want those brands to know me in return. The ideal purchase is one that only someone who truly understands both the brand and my own aesthetic could have made.
archetypes.needs: I need deep product knowledge from the people who serve me ‚Äî not a recitation of features but an understanding of why a particular piece belongs in my collection. I research through brand heritage archives, collector communities and auction records. I respond to rarity, limited production and provenance documentation. I am deeply loyal to brands that remember my history with them and treat the relationship as accumulative.
archetypes.touchpoints: Flagship stores, private client advisors, collector events and brand heritage communications are my primary channels. I engage with brand content when it demonstrates genuine craft intelligence rather than marketing gloss. Auction houses and resale platforms inform my understanding of a piece's cultural value. I am not on social media for shopping ‚Äî I am there for cultural participation.
expectations: Advisor who knows their collection history
Proactive access to rare pieces before general release
Deep craft and provenance narratives
Private client relationship continuity
barriers: Generic sales approach
Advisor who doesn't know their history
Mass availability of pieces they were told were rare
Brand dilution through licensing or accessibility plays
drivers: Being genuinely known by the brand
triggers: New collection with a piece that fits their narrative
Cultural moment associated with a brand
solution_principles: Because the relationship is biographical and accumulative, every advisor interaction must begin from a complete knowledge of the client's history ‚Äî what they own, what they passed on and what they are looking for next.
Because rarity is the core value proposition, access to limited pieces must be given to known collectors before general release ‚Äî exclusivity promised but not delivered is a permanent trust break.
Because craft narrative is as important as the object, every product communication must go deeper than specification ‚Äî the story of how something was made is part of what is being sold.

archetypes.name: The Gifting Patron
archetypes.latin: Dono Ergo Amo (I Give Therefore I Love)
archetypes.description: I buy luxury primarily for others. The purchase is an emotional act ‚Äî a declaration of love, a milestone acknowledgement, a relationship maintained through considered generosity. The object is almost secondary to the experience of giving it: the wrapping, the presentation, the story I can tell about why I chose this particular thing for this particular person. I need the brand to do the emotional heavy lifting that I cannot always articulate myself.
archetypes.goals: I want the recipient to feel that this gift was chosen specifically for them ‚Äî not purchased from a brand they happened to know. I want the brand to help me find the right thing, frame it beautifully and deliver it in a way that communicates the care I intended. The measure of success is the reaction of the person receiving it, not my own satisfaction with the purchase.
archetypes.needs: I need gifting expertise from advisors ‚Äî the ability to translate a relationship, a personality and an occasion into a specific recommendation. I need impeccable packaging that communicates luxury before the gift is opened. I need reliable delivery for time-sensitive occasions. I research through brand gifting guides, editorial recommendations and peer suggestions. I am deeply frustrated by gift experiences that feel impersonal or generic.
archetypes.touchpoints: Brand flagship stores and concierge services are my primary purchase channels for significant gifts. I use brand websites for research and discovery. I engage with gift guides in luxury editorial. I am increasingly using personalisation services and bespoke options for important occasions. I notice and judge the quality of packaging as a signal of brand seriousness.
expectations: Advisor who asks the right questions about the recipient
Flawless packaging as part of the product
Reliable delivery for occasion dates
Personalisation or engraving options
barriers: Generic advisor approach
Packaging that doesn't match the price
Late delivery on a time-critical occasion
No ability to personalise or customise
triggers: Desire to express gratitude or love
Previous gifting success that set the standard
solution_principles: Because the purchase is fundamentally about the recipient's experience, the gifting conversation must begin with questions about the person receiving the gift ‚Äî not the product range available.
Because packaging is the first emotional moment, the unboxing experience must be designed with the same rigour as the product ‚Äî it is the opening act of the story the giver is telling.
Because a late delivery on a milestone occasion is an unforgivable failure, gifting timelines must be managed with the same operational seriousness as any time-critical promise.

archetypes.name: The Conscious Connoisseur
archetypes.description: I value craftsmanship, provenance and ethical production above logo recognition. I am deeply suspicious of conspicuous luxury ‚Äî I prefer the quiet signal of genuine quality that only the truly informed will recognise. I research obsessively: who made this, how it was made, under what conditions and with what materials. I am as interested in the supply chain as the finished product. A brand's sustainability claims are not marketing to me ‚Äî they are a standard I will verify.
archetypes.goals: I want to own things that are made properly ‚Äî by people paid fairly, with materials sourced responsibly, built to last decades rather than seasons. I want the luxury market to use its margin to lead on ethics, not to follow reluctantly. I want to be able to wear something with pride not just because it is beautiful but because I know the story behind it is one I can stand behind.
archetypes.needs: I need radical transparency ‚Äî full supply chain visibility, material sourcing documentation, artisan profiles and production ethics certifications. I research through sustainability watchdogs, ethical fashion journalism and brand audit reports. I am not swayed by greenwashing and I am fluent enough in sustainability language to identify it immediately. I respond to authenticity and am repelled by performative gestures.
archetypes.touchpoints: Ethical fashion journalism, sustainability rating platforms, brand transparency reports and artisan-focused editorial are my primary discovery channels. I engage deeply with brand content when it demonstrates genuine commitment rather than marketing positioning. I share my discoveries and critiques actively in the communities I belong to. A brand that earns my trust earns a vocal advocate.
expectations: Full supply chain transparency
Material sourcing documentation
Sustainability commitments with measurable targets
Repair and longevity services
barriers: Greenwashing detected in brand claims
Opacity around production conditions
Planned obsolescence in product design
Sustainability as a marketing campaign not a commitment
triggers: New brand discovery with genuine credentials
Product reaching end of life and repair decision
solution_principles: Because transparency is the product for this archetype, supply chain visibility must be complete, accessible and written for a sceptical expert ‚Äî not a reassured consumer.
Because greenwashing is detected immediately and shared publicly, every sustainability claim must be backed by third-party verification, measurable targets and honest reporting of shortfalls.

Because longevity is a core value, repair services, material guarantees and product lifetime support must be prominently offered ‚Äî they are part of the ethical product proposition, not an afterthought.

archetypes.name: The Social Signaller
archetypes.latin: Videor Ergo Sum (I Am Seen Therefore I Am)
archetypes.description: I buy luxury for visibility ‚Äî in rooms, in photographs, on social media. The item is content before it is clothing. I am deeply attuned to what is trending, what is about to trend, and what signals the right cultural moment. I am both audience and amplifier: my purchase decision is shaped by what I see, and what I buy shapes what others see. My loyalty follows cultural relevance ‚Äî the moment a brand loses the conversation, it loses me.
archetypes.goals: I want to be seen wearing the right thing at the right moment ‚Äî the piece that communicates cultural fluency, not just wealth. I want access to limited drops, collaborations and brand moments before they become widely available. I want the brands I wear to be generating conversation, not just revenue. Being seen in something before it becomes mainstream is the peak experience.
archetypes.needs: I need brands to be culturally alive ‚Äî in the right collaborations, with the right talent, at the right moments. I research through social media, fashion week coverage, influencer content and cultural commentary. I am highly sensitive to brand missteps and cancel culture moves swiftly in my community. I engage with brand social content when it feels genuinely creative, and I scroll past anything that feels like a paid post.
archetypes.touchpoints: Instagram, TikTok, YouTube fashion commentary and influencer communities are my primary discovery channels. I attend pop-ups, launches and brand moments that generate shareable content. I use brand websites and apps primarily for purchase after discovery has happened elsewhere. I am a content creator by default ‚Äî everything I buy becomes content before it becomes possession.
expectations: Early access to limited drops
Brand cultural relevance in real time
Shareable product and brand moments
Digital-first purchasing experience
barriers: Brand losing cultural relevance
Product becoming too widely available
Poor social media content quality
Brand misstep or cancel moment
solution_principles: Because cultural relevance is the primary loyalty driver, the brand must be genuinely present in cultural conversations ‚Äî not sponsoring them from the outside but generating them from within.

Because the purchase is content before it is possession, the digital and physical purchasing experience must be designed to be shareable ‚Äî the moment of acquisition is as important as the product itself.

Because early access is the highest form of recognition for this archetype, limited drops and collaborations must be shared with community-connected customers before general release ‚Äî not as a loyalty mechanic, but as cultural partnership.

archetypes.name: The Quiet Luxury Seeker
archetypes.description: I wear luxury for myself, not for the room. The logos are either absent or so small that only those who know will notice. I am affluent enough that I no longer need to prove it. I buy quality that communicates taste to the discerning eye and says nothing whatsoever to the uninformed.
