I am attracted to brands that understand restraint as the ultimate luxury ‚Äî that the absence of obvious signalling is itself the signal.
archetypes.goals: I want clothes and objects that are impeccably made, that last for decades and that make me feel quietly, privately excellent. I want the craft to be so refined that the only conversation about it happens between people who truly understand. I want to own less and own better. I measure quality by how something feels to wear, not by how it photographs.
archetypes.needs: I need exceptional material quality, perfect construction and a brand philosophy that prioritises longevity over trend. I research through trusted tastemakers, specialist craft publications and long-standing brand relationships. I am not on social media for fashion discovery. I respond to restraint in brand communication ‚Äî minimal copy, genuine craft content, no celebrity endorsement. I build wardrobes over years, not seasons.
archetypes.touchpoints: Specialist tailors, craft-focused boutiques, trusted style editors and long-standing brand relationships are my discovery channels. I engage with brand content very selectively ‚Äî only when it demonstrates genuine craft intelligence. I visit flagship stores rarely but with high intention. I prefer to know the person who serves me by name. I buy from brands where I trust that the quality will not change when ownership changes.
expectations: Advisor known to them personally
Material and construction excellence
Longevity guarantee and repair service
Minimal brand communication that respects their intelligence
barriers: Brand communication that shouts
Quality decline after ownership change
Too-wide distribution diluting exclusivity
Celebrity endorsement cheapening the brand
triggers: Garment reaching end of life and needing replacement
Discovery of a new craft brand through trusted source
Significant life milestone requiring a considered purchase
solution_principles: Because restraint is the luxury, every brand communication must be edited to the minimum necessary ‚Äî less copy, more craft evidence, zero celebrity noise.

Because quality is promised over decades not seasons, repair services, material guarantees and lifetime product support must be built into the brand proposition ‚Äî not offered reluctantly when asked.
Because the advisor relationship is part of the product, client continuity must be protected ‚Äî a change of advisor without consultation and warm introduction is a meaningful relationship break.

archetypes.name: The Aspirational Newcomer
archetypes.description: I am making my first serious luxury purchases ‚Äî moving from high street and accessible premium into genuine luxury for the first time. The experience is exciting and slightly intimidating. I am very aware of what I don't know and deeply sensitive to being made to feel that I don't belong. I have worked hard to be able to afford this and I want the brand to meet that effort with genuine welcome, not patrician tolerance.
archetypes.goals: I want to feel that luxury was made for me too ‚Äî that my money and my aspiration are as valid as those of someone who has been a customer for twenty years. I want to leave my first luxury purchase having learned something and feeling genuinely welcomed. I want a brand that invests in my future loyalty rather than processing my current transaction.
archetypes.needs: I need advisors who educate without condescending ‚Äî who explain the craft, the heritage and the care requirements without making me feel like an outsider. I research heavily online before entering any store ‚Äî YouTube guides, Reddit luxury communities, brand history deep-dives. I know more than I let on. I am testing the brand as much as I am shopping in it, and I will share my experience extensively.
archetypes.touchpoints: YouTube luxury guides, Reddit communities like r/malefashionadvice and r/femalefashionadvice, TikTok luxury content and brand websites are my primary research channels. I enter the store having completed significant digital research. I am acutely sensitive to how I am received at the door and in the first thirty seconds of interaction. Post-purchase, I share my experience in the communities where I learned.
expectations: Warm welcome regardless of apparent familiarity with luxury
Education without condescension
First purchase treated as the beginning of a relationship
Post-purchase follow-up and care guidance
barriers: Intimidating store environments
Advisors who assess spend before engagement
Assumed knowledge in product conversations
Being made to feel that they don't belong
triggers: Peer luxury purchase inspiring their own
Gift from someone else introducing them to the brand
solution_principles: Because the first impression determines whether a decades-long relationship begins or ends, every new customer must be received with the same warmth and investment as a known collector ‚Äî the potential value is identical.

Because they arrive knowing more than they show, the advisor conversation must begin with discovery ‚Äî asking what drew them to this piece ‚Äî not with a product recitation that underestimates their research.

Because they will share this experience extensively in the communities where future customers are learning, the first luxury purchase experience is a brand marketing moment that reaches far beyond the individual transaction.

archetypes.name: The Investment Buyer
archetypes.description: I buy luxury with one eye on the product and one eye on the secondary market. Watches, handbags, jewellery, limited editions ‚Äî these are asset classes as much as they are possessions. I track resale values, auction results and edition scarcity with the same attention I give to equities. I have learned that the best luxury investments sit at the intersection of genuine craft, brand heat and controlled supply. I am disciplined and patient.
archetypes.goals: I want pieces that hold or appreciate in value while also being genuinely beautiful to own. I want access to allocation products ‚Äî the watches and bags that are invitation-only at retail and command significant premiums on the secondary market. I want a relationship with the brand that grants me access commensurate with my spend history. I measure the success of a purchase partially by its resale trajectory.
archetypes.needs: I need provenance documentation, authentication certificates and purchase records that support secondary market value. I research through watch and bag investment forums, auction house results, resale platform pricing data and collector intelligence networks. I am deeply loyal to brands that control supply seriously and deeply critical of those that chase short-term revenue with increased production.
archetypes.touchpoints: Watch and handbag investment forums, auction house communications, authorised dealer networks and resale market platforms are my primary channels. I maintain relationships with multiple authorised dealers to improve allocation access. I track brand supply decisions with the attention of a market analyst. I attend brand events selectively ‚Äî primarily those where allocation relationships are built.
expectations: Allocation access commensurate with spend history
Complete provenance and authentication documentation
Supply discipline maintained by brand
Secondary market value transparency
barriers: Allocation given to lower-spend clients
Production increases diluting scarcity value
Documentation gaps affecting resale
Brand decisions prioritising revenue over supply discipline
triggers: Secondary market pricing signalling purchase moment
solution_principles: Because supply discipline is the foundation of investment value, production decisions must be made with long-term collector trust in mind ‚Äî a production increase for short-term revenue destroys the investment proposition permanently.

Because allocation access is the primary relationship currency, a transparent and merit-based allocation system tied to spend history must exist and be consistently honoured ‚Äî perceived favouritism is a loyalty-ending discovery.

Because provenance documentation directly affects resale value, purchase records, authentication certificates and service histories must be maintained by the brand and made fully accessible to the owner at all times.

archetypes.name: The Fashion Insider
archetypes.latin: Ante Omnes Scio (I Know Before Everyone)
archetypes.description: I live inside the fashion industry ‚Äî as a creative, a stylist, a buyer, a journalist or a deeply embedded enthusiast. My relationship with luxury brands is professional as much as personal. I understand the design calendar, the creative director's references, the supply chain constraints and the commercial pressures. I form opinions about collections before they are presented and I share them in the communities where brand reputation is made or dismantled. I am the person whose endorsement matters most and whose critique lands hardest.
archetypes.goals: I want to be treated as a genuine peer by the brands I engage with ‚Äî not as a consumer who happens to know a lot. I want early access to collections, invitations to presentations and conversations with creative teams that go beyond brand messaging. I want to feel that the brands I support see me as part of their cultural ecosystem, not a press opportunity.
archetypes.needs: I need access that reflects my position ‚Äî preview invitations, showroom access, creative team engagement and press communications that treat me as an industry peer. I research through show coverage, industry publications, designer interviews and my own network of industry contacts. I am deeply critical of brands that engage with insiders transactionally rather than relationally. My advocacy cannot be bought ‚Äî it must be earned.
archetypes.touchpoints: Fashion weeks, press days, showroom appointments, industry events and insider communications are my primary channels. I engage with brand social content critically ‚Äî I notice what is authentic and what is positioned. I write, post and speak about brands in communities that shape industry and consumer perception alike. My relationship with a brand's PR and communications team is as important as my relationship with the product.
expectations: Industry peer treatment not consumer treatment
Early collection access and showroom invitations
Creative team engagement beyond brand messaging
Consistency of relationship across brand touchpoints
barriers: Transactional press engagement
Being treated as a consumer not a peer
Brand messaging that assumes no prior knowledge
Relationship inconsistency when PR contacts change
triggers: New collection generating genuine creative interest
Brand making a significant creative or strategic shift
solution_principles: Because industry insiders shape brand perception before consumers form opinions, PR and communications must treat this archetype as a cultural partner ‚Äî with genuine creative access and relationship continuity, not managed press appearances.

Because their advocacy is earned not purchased, the brand must invest in relationships that have intellectual and creative depth ‚Äî invitations, access and conversations that go meaningfully beyond product presentation.

Because a critical insider voice travels further than any campaign, every interaction must be conducted with the awareness that this person will share it in the communities where brand reputation is actually built.

automotive.label: Automotive
automotive.description: Buyers navigating a high-involvement, emotionally charged purchase across new, used, electric and performance vehicles ‚Äî from research through ownership and beyond.

archetypes.name: The Precision Driver
archetypes.description: I buy with engineering specifications as my primary language. I have read every comparison test, watched every track review and arrived at the showroom knowing more than most of the people who work there. Performance data is my love language ‚Äî power-to-weight ratios, braking distances, suspension geometry, lap times. Emotion follows specifications for me, not the other way around. I respect genuine expertise and I am permanently repelled by oversell and theatrical showroom performance.
archetypes.goals: I want to own the most dynamically capable vehicle in my price bracket ‚Äî and I want to know, with data, that I have achieved that. I want a buying experience that respects my knowledge rather than performing knowledge for me. I want ownership that delivers on the engineering promise made during the sale ‚Äî consistently, reliably, and without the dealer needing to be reminded what they sold me.
archetypes.needs: I need genuine technical depth from the people selling and servicing my vehicle. I research through automotive journalism, manufacturer technical documentation, owner forums and professional test driver assessments. I am not moved by lifestyle photography ‚Äî I want to see the car on a wet road in a comparison test. I will switch brands when the engineering story of a competitor becomes more compelling than loyalty.
archetypes.touchpoints: Specialist automotive press, manufacturer technical content, owner forums, YouTube car review channels and trackday communities are my primary channels. I visit showrooms with a prepared agenda. I engage with service teams as technical partners. I attend manufacturer driving events when the access to the car is genuine rather than managed.
expectations: Technical staff who know the product at depth
Access to genuine performance test drives
Honest specification comparisons
Service team who treat them as a technical peer
barriers: Salespeople who recite brochure copy
Lifestyle-only marketing with no engineering substance
Manufacturer claims that don't match tested reality
Service teams who dismiss driver feedback
triggers: New model launch with compelling engineering story
Competitor achieving meaningfully better performance metrics
Trackday or drive event revealing limitations of current car
Owner forum consensus shifting to a new model
solution_principles: Because technical credibility is the primary trust currency, every sales and service interaction must be staffed by people with genuine product knowledge ‚Äî not managed enthusiasm trained to deflect detailed questions.

Because the test drive is the proof of the engineering promise, it must be long enough, varied enough and unscripted enough to reveal the car's actual dynamic character ‚Äî a carpark circuit is an insult.

Because they will fact-check every claim in owner forums, marketing and specification communications must be technically accurate and never overstate ‚Äî a single provable exaggeration damages all future claims.

archetypes.name: The Conscious Commuter
archetypes.description: I am switching to an electric vehicle ‚Äî or have already switched ‚Äî and my motivation is genuinely values-driven as much as it is practical. This is a statement about the kind of world I want to contribute to, not just a calculation about fuel costs. I am not a zealot but I am committed, and I need the brand to match that commitment with honesty. I have no patience for greenwashing and I can usually identify it within one paragraph of marketing copy.
archetypes.goals: I want a vehicle that genuinely reduces my environmental impact while being genuinely capable in daily use. I want range anxiety resolved not minimised ‚Äî real-world range data, charging network reliability and honest comparisons between stated and delivered performance. I want my purchase to be defensible to myself and to others, which means the whole-life environmental calculation needs to hold up to scrutiny.
archetypes.needs: I need honest real-world range data, charging infrastructure mapped to my actual routes, total cost of ownership modelled against my current vehicle and a clear view of the battery lifecycle and end-of-life plan. I research through EV owner communities, independent range testing, sustainability journalism and total cost of ownership calculators. I am more influenced by a frank acknowledgement of current limitations than by optimistic marketing.
archetypes.touchpoints: EV owner communities, independent range testing platforms, sustainability journalism, YouTube EV review channels and charging network apps are my primary channels. I visit dealerships with specific real-world questions. I engage heavily with the owner community before purchase and become part of it immediately after. My real-world experience becomes content that influences the next wave of switchers.
expectations: Honest real-world range data not WLTP figures
Charging infrastructure mapped to their routes
Whole-life environmental impact transparency
Battery lifecycle and end-of-life plan
barriers: Greenwashing detected in brand claims
Gap between stated and real-world range
Charging network reliability gaps
Insufficient honest acknowledgement of current limitations
triggers: Running cost calculation reaching tipping point
Peer EV purchase sharing positive experience
New model resolving previous range or charging concern
solution_principles: Because honesty about limitations builds more trust than optimistic claims, real-world range, charging times and infrastructure gaps must be communicated transparently ‚Äî a buyer who discovers the truth later becomes a vocal critic.

Because the whole-life environmental calculation matters to them, the brand must provide credible, third-party verified lifecycle carbon data ‚Äî greenwashing is not just ineffective, it is actively damaging with this archetype.

Because range anxiety is behavioural not rational, onboarding must include practical confidence-building ‚Äî route planning tools, charging network orientation and a supported first long journey ‚Äî not just a handover document.

archetypes.name: The Status Commuter
archetypes.latin: Conspicuus in Via (Visible on the Road)
archetypes.description: My car is a visible indicator of where I am in life ‚Äî and where I am headed. The badge on the bonnet matters enormously. I am not buying transport; I am buying an arrival. Financing makes the aspirational accessible and I am entirely comfortable with that calculus. I am attracted by launch events, the theatre of the personalisation process and the ceremony of handover. My car should make me feel that I have made it ‚Äî every morning when I walk towards it.
archetypes.goals: I want a vehicle that communicates success without requiring explanation. I want the brand to be unambiguously premium ‚Äî recognised by everyone, aspirational to many. I want the personalisation process to feel like tailoring, not configuration. I want the handover to be a moment, not an admin exercise. I want colleagues and peers to notice, and for the noticing to feel natural rather than forced.
archetypes.needs: I need a purchase experience that feels commensurate with the aspiration. I research through premium automotive press, social media and the cars I see in the car parks of people I respect. The showroom must feel like a destination, not a depot. I need a finance package that makes monthly payments feel manageable and the total spend feel justified. I am loyal to the brand that makes me feel most like the person I am becoming.
archetypes.touchpoints: Premium automotive press, social media ‚Äî particularly Instagram ‚Äî aspirational lifestyle content and peer observation are my discovery channels. The showroom experience carries significant weight. I engage with brand events and launches when they feel exclusive. I share my purchase and handover experience on social media and my reaction is shaped entirely by how the brand makes that moment feel.
expectations: Showroom that feels like a premium destination
Personalisation process that feels like tailoring
Handover that feels like a ceremony
Finance that makes aspiration feel accessible and dignified
barriers: Showroom that feels functional rather than aspirational
Handover treated as a paperwork exercise
Finance process that makes them feel scrutinised rather than welcomed
Personalisation options that feel limited or generic
triggers: Current car feeling behind aspirational position
solution_principles: Because the purchase is an emotional arrival, the handover must be choreographed as a ceremony ‚Äî time, attention, presentation and a moment that is worth photographing and sharing.
Because personalisation communicates identity, the configuration process must feel like creative collaboration with a brand expert, not a menu selection from a screen.

Because the showroom is the brand made physical, every element of the dealership environment must communicate premium without apology ‚Äî the coffee, the seating, the lighting and the people are all part of the product.

archetypes.name: The Rational Switcher
archetypes.description: A car is expensive transport. Full stop. I respect good engineering but I am not emotionally attached to any badge. I compare on depreciation curves, insurance groups, fuel or charging costs, service intervals and reliability data before I consider anything else. I find dealership theatre mildly irritating. I want transparent pricing, a clear total cost of ownership model and a purchase process that I can complete as efficiently as possible. If I can do it without visiting a dealership, I prefer it.
archetypes.goals: I want the best whole-life cost vehicle for my usage pattern, and I want to be confident I have found it. I measure success by the gap between what I expected to pay across three years of ownership and what I actually paid. I have no interest in being sold a service plan I didn't ask for or a paint protection package that a spreadsheet tells me doesn't hold its value.
archetypes.needs: I need total cost of ownership calculators, transparent pricing with no dealer margin mystery, reliability data from independent sources and a buying process with minimum friction. I research through consumer reports, independent reliability surveys, depreciation tracking platforms and owner communities focused on ownership costs. I am most comfortable completing as much of the purchase process online as possible before any human contact.
archetypes.touchpoints: Consumer reports, depreciation tracking platforms, independent reliability surveys, comparison sites and online configurators are my primary research channels. I engage with dealerships only when necessary and I arrive with every number already checked. I respond positively to brands that offer transparent online pricing and digital purchase journeys. I become a loyal customer only if the ownership cost reality matches the buying process promise.
expectations: All-in transparent pricing with no hidden extras
Total cost of ownership data readily available
Digital purchase journey completable without dealership visit
No cross-selling of products they didn't request
barriers: Opaque dealer pricing structures
Forced dealership visits for information available online
Aggressive upselling during the purchase process
Gap between advertised and actual cost of ownership
triggers: Current vehicle reaching optimal replacement point on depreciation curve
Running cost calculation showing better alternative
solution_principles: Because transparency is the entire value proposition for this archetype, pricing must be all-in, upfront and consistent ‚Äî any gap discovered between advertised and actual price is a permanent trust break.
Because their ideal journey is mostly digital, the online configurator and purchase pathway must be complete enough that a dealership visit is a choice, not a requirement.
Because upselling is experienced as disrespect, every additional product or service must be offered once, clearly, with honest value framing ‚Äî and accepted when declined without repeat or pressure.

archetypes.name: The Adventure Seeker
archetypes.description: I buy a vehicle as the enabler of a lifestyle, not as a status object or a commuting tool. Off-road capability, towing capacity, load space, roof rack compatibility and ground clearance are my specification language. The dealership experience should feel like a base camp briefing ‚Äî someone who understands where I am going and what I need the vehicle to do when I get there. Community is as important as the vehicle itself: I want to belong to a tribe of owners doing the same things.
archetypes.goals: I want a vehicle that removes limits from my adventures rather than adding them. I want to go places that most cars cannot follow. I want to know that my vehicle is capable of more than I will ever ask of it, and I want a brand that understands that this confidence is what I am buying. I want to be part of an owner community where capability is shared and adventures are planned.
archetypes.needs: I need genuine off-road or capability specifications ‚Äî not a softroader with adventure marketing applied. I research through overlanding communities, 4x4 owner clubs, adventure travel YouTube channels and manufacturer off-road event coverage. I am deeply unimpressed by lifestyle imagery of capable vehicles in urban settings. I need accessory compatibility information, roof load ratings and recovery point specifications as standard product information.
archetypes.touchpoints: Overlanding communities, 4x4 owner clubs, adventure travel YouTube channels, outdoor lifestyle events and manufacturer off-road experiences are my primary channels. I engage with brands that invest in genuine off-road events rather than curated photoshoots. I share my own adventures extensively and my vehicle features prominently in that content. The owner community's verdict on a vehicle matters more to me than any press review.
expectations: Genuine off-road capability specs not lifestyle marketing
Accessory and modification ecosystem information
Owner community access from point of purchase
Service capability in remote or specialist areas
barriers: Urban lifestyle imagery applied to capable vehicles
Capability claims not backed by genuine specification
No owner community or event programme
Dealership staff with no genuine off-road knowledge
drivers: Vehicle as identity expression of values
solution_principles: Because community is as much of the product as the vehicle, owner club access, event programmes and community platforms must be built into the brand proposition and activated at point of purchase.

Because genuine capability is the promise and lifestyle marketing is the betrayal, every specification claim must be backed by genuine off-road testing data and communicated in the language of capability, not aspiration.

Because dealership knowledge is part of the purchase experience, sales staff for adventure-capable vehicles must have genuine experience with the vehicle in the conditions it is designed for ‚Äî not product training delivered in a classroom.

archetypes.name: The Family Pragmatist
archetypes.latin: Omnia Pro Familia (Everything for the Family)
archetypes.description: I need a vehicle that works for a family ‚Äî not the family from the brochure but my actual family, with its specific mixture of ages, activities, car seats, dogs, sports equipment and irregular schedules. I am not excited about this purchase in the way some people are excited about cars. I am making a large, considered decision about a functional object that will affect daily life for the next three to five years. I need to get it right and I need it to not let me down.
archetypes.goals: I want a vehicle that genuinely fits my family's actual daily reality ‚Äî not a demonstration of what the car can do on a perfect day, but evidence that it will work reliably on every imperfect one. I want the ownership experience to be uncomplicated: service bookings that fit around a busy life, warranty coverage that I never have to argue about, and a boot that fits a pushchair without a puzzle.
archetypes.needs: I need honest practicality data ‚Äî real boot volumes, actual seat configuration flexibility, genuine ISOFIX and car seat compatibility, fuel economy in mixed real-world driving. I research through family car review sites, parent communities and owner feedback on reliability and running costs. I am deeply influenced by peer recommendations from parents with similar family configurations. I need flexible servicing arrangements and a dealer who understands that I cannot drop the car off and wait.
archetypes.touchpoints: Family car review platforms, parent communities, consumer reliability reports and peer recommendations from parents are my primary channels. I engage with brand websites for specification and configurator tools. I visit the dealership expecting a practical demonstration ‚Äî not a performance. I need to physically put the car seat in and put the buggy in the boot before I decide.
expectations: Honest real-world practicality data
Dealership that accommodates family logistics
Warranty coverage with no grey areas
Service flexibility around school and work schedules
barriers: Brochure practicality that doesn't match reality
Service processes that assume a free day
Warranty claims that require argument
Salespeople who pitch performance to someone asking about boot space
triggers: Child reaching car seat transition age
solution_principles: Because daily family reliability is the entire value proposition, warranty terms must be genuinely comprehensive and claims must be processed without requiring the customer to argue ‚Äî every disputed claim becomes a community story.

Because the test drive serves a practical not emotional purpose, the dealership must facilitate a proper family test ‚Äî child seats in, buggy in the boot, actual family in the car ‚Äî before any other conversation.
Because service logistics are a genuine barrier for busy families, collection and delivery servicing, loaner vehicles and flexible booking must be standard ‚Äî not premium additions.

archetypes.name: The Tech Early Adopter
archetypes.latin: Primus in Nova (First into the New)
archetypes.description: I buy the most technologically advanced vehicle available at each purchasing cycle. The car is a rolling technology platform to me ‚Äî autonomous driving features, over-the-air updates, AI-assisted systems, connected services and sensor sophistication are my primary evaluation criteria. I am comfortable with first-generation technology and I expect the brand to treat me as a partner in its development, not a customer to be managed around its limitations.
archetypes.goals: I want to be driving the most technologically sophisticated vehicle on the road. I want over-the-air updates that genuinely improve the vehicle over time. I want autonomous and semi-autonomous features that work reliably enough to use daily. I want the connected ecosystem to be genuinely useful ‚Äî not a collection of features that work beautifully in demos and frustrate in daily use.
archetypes.needs: I need detailed technical specifications on software architecture, sensor specifications, update cadence and autonomy capability mapping. I research through technology journalism, developer communities, beta tester forums and manufacturer technical communications. I want access to the software development roadmap and I am willing to participate in beta programmes. I am deeply critical of features that are marketed as ready but ship as incomplete.
archetypes.touchpoints: Technology journalism, EV and autonomous driving forums, software update communities, developer-facing brand content and YouTube technology reviewers are my primary channels. I engage directly with brand technology teams when access is available. I am an active beta tester and contributor to owner communities focused on software capabilities. I share detailed technical reviews that influence the next wave of technology buyers.
expectations: Detailed software and sensor specifications
Honest autonomy capability mapping
Over-the-air update transparency and cadence
Beta programme access and genuine feedback loops
barriers: Features marketed as complete that ship as incomplete
No software development roadmap transparency
Update cadence that doesn't match purchase promise
Being managed around technology limitations rather than partnered through them
triggers: New model with significant technology leap
Software update enabling previously unavailable capability
Technology community generating interest in new platform
important_steps: Update cycle engagement and community contribution
solution_principles: Because technology promise drives purchase and technology delivery determines loyalty, every feature claim must have a delivery date and that date must be met ‚Äî a delayed or incomplete feature is not a software update, it is a broken promise.

Because they want to be partners not customers, beta programmes, update notes and software roadmaps must be communicated with the transparency of a developer relationship, not the caution of a marketing department.

Because their detailed public reviews shape the perception of the next generation of buyers, direct channels to technology teams and genuine feedback loops must exist ‚Äî not filtered through a customer service layer that cannot answer technical questions.

archetypes.name: The Used Car Realist
archetypes.description: I buy used because it is the intelligent financial decision ‚Äî someone else has already absorbed the depreciation hit and I benefit from it. I am not settling; I am optimising. I approach the used car market with eyes fully open: I know about clocked mileage, undisclosed accident damage and inflated provenance claims. I am a careful, sceptical buyer who does substantial due diligence. The dealer who earns my trust with complete honesty earns my business and my referral.
archetypes.goals: I want the best specification vehicle available within my budget, with a clean and verifiable history, at a price that reflects actual market value rather than dealer margin aspiration. I want transparency about everything that is not perfect ‚Äî a car with a known and disclosed minor issue is more trustworthy to me than a car presented as flawless. I want the purchase protected by genuine warranty coverage.
archetypes.needs: I need full provenance documentation, independent vehicle history checks, transparent service records and a warranty that actually covers meaningful failure. I research through used car platforms, vehicle history check services, independent inspection providers and owner communities for the specific models I am considering. I approach every used car negotiation as an information asymmetry problem that I am working to resolve.
archetypes.touchpoints: Used car platforms, vehicle history check services, manufacturer certified used programmes, independent inspection services and model-specific owner forums are my primary channels. I engage with dealers who provide complete documentation proactively and I disengage immediately when information is withheld or qualified. I share my buying experience publicly and my review of the dealer's honesty is as important as the vehicle itself.
expectations: Full provenance and service history documentation
Proactive disclosure of any known issues
Independent inspection facilitation
Warranty that covers meaningful mechanical failure
barriers: Information withheld or qualified when asked directly
Provenance claims that don't match documentation
Warranty exclusions that make coverage meaningless
Negotiation tactics that feel adversarial
triggers: Specific model becoming available at right price
Depreciation calculation reaching optimal purchase window
mindset: Publicly sharing of dealer honesty verdict
solution_principles: Because information asymmetry is the used car market's defining problem, proactive and complete disclosure ‚Äî including minor issues ‚Äî is not just ethical but a commercial strategy: transparent dealers earn trust that translates to premium pricing and referrals.

Because warranty coverage is the primary risk mitigation, warranty terms must be genuinely comprehensive and written in plain language ‚Äî exclusion-heavy small print is discovered and shared publicly by this archetype.

Because they share dealer verdicts in communities where future buyers research, the honesty of the buying interaction is a marketing asset ‚Äî a reputation for transparency in the used market is worth more than any campaign.

ecommerce.label: E-Commerce & Marketplace
ecommerce.description: Online shoppers navigating choice, convenience, trust, delivery and returns across retail platforms, marketplaces and direct-to-consumer brands.

archetypes.name: The Instant Gratifier
archetypes.description: Speed is my primary value proposition ‚Äî in discovery, in purchase and in delivery. I decided what I want in minutes and I expect to have it in hours. Cart abandonment spikes at every additional click, every mandatory account creation, every checkout step that could have been removed. I pay a premium for same-day delivery without hesitation. I use returns as a built-in risk mitigation that I expect to be frictionless. Loyalty belongs entirely to whoever is fastest ‚Äî the moment a competitor can do it quicker, the relationship ends.
archetypes.goals: I want to close the gap between wanting something and having it as completely as technology will allow. I want a purchase experience so frictionless that the decision and the delivery feel like a single moment. I want my previous preferences, addresses and payment methods remembered perfectly so that the path from desire to ownership is measured in seconds not minutes.
archetypes.needs: I need one-click purchasing, saved preferences, real-time stock visibility and delivery windows measured in hours not days. I research impulsively ‚Äî a recommendation, a social post, a search result ‚Äî and I convert immediately when the path is clear. I am deeply intolerant of checkout friction: mandatory fields, address verification delays, payment processing errors. I expect returns to be initiated in one step with immediate collection.
archetypes.touchpoints: Social media discovery ‚Äî Instagram, TikTok, Pinterest ‚Äî feeds directly into purchase intent for me. I use apps not browsers. Push notifications with genuine relevance drive re-engagement. Same-day and next-day delivery tracking is part of the product experience. I rate the delivery experience as much as the product itself and my reviews reflect both.
expectations: One-click or saved-preference checkout
Same-day or next-day delivery as standard
Frictionless returns initiated in one step
Real-time delivery tracking from dispatch to door
barriers: Mandatory account creation before purchase
Multi-step checkout with avoidable fields
Delivery windows measured in days not hours
Returns requiring printed labels or post office visits
drivers: Minimum time between desire and possession
solution_principles: Because every additional step is a dropout risk, the path from product discovery to purchase confirmation must be completable in under sixty seconds for a returning customer ‚Äî every field, every click and every redirect must justify its existence.

Because delivery speed is a loyalty driver as powerful as product quality, same-day and next-day capability must be treated as core infrastructure investment, not a premium tier ‚Äî the brand that is fastest owns this archetype.

Because frictionless returns remove the primary purchase risk, return initiation must be a single action from order history, with collection rather than drop-off as the default ‚Äî the effort of returning should never exceed the ease of buying.

archetypes.name: The Research Rabbit
archetypes.description: I spend longer researching a ¬£40 purchase than most people spend on a car. The tabs multiply ‚Äî comparison sites, Reddit threads, YouTube unboxings, specialist forums, Amazon reviews filtered by verified purchase, brand website claims cross-referenced against independent tests. The research is genuinely enjoyable to me. The purchase is almost anticlimactic ‚Äî an administrative conclusion to the real activity. I need rich product content, authentic and detailed reviews, and comparison infrastructure that respects my intelligence.
archetypes.goals: I want to arrive at a purchase decision with complete confidence that I have found the objectively best option for my specific requirements. I want to understand every relevant dimension of a product before I commit. I want the research process to be supported by the brand ‚Äî with detailed specifications, honest comparisons and content that adds to my knowledge rather than simply promoting a sale.
archetypes.needs: I need depth ‚Äî full technical specifications, third-party review aggregation, detailed Q&A sections, comparison tools, video content that goes beyond marketing and written content that acknowledges what a product does not do as well as what it does. I research over days or weeks for significant purchases. I am deeply frustrated by information gaps that force me to look elsewhere and I follow the information wherever it leads, regardless of which brand provides it.
archetypes.touchpoints: Reddit communities, specialist forums, YouTube product reviews, comparison platforms and consumer review sites are my primary research channels. I engage with brand websites primarily for technical specifications. I use review filter tools extensively ‚Äî sorting by most critical, filtering by verified purchase, reading one-star reviews first. I am an active reviewer myself and my reviews are detailed, fair and specific.
expectations: Full technical specifications not marketing summaries
Authentic and detailed review ecosystem
Honest comparison tools including competitor mention
Q&A sections answered by verified users and brand
barriers: Specification gaps that force external research
Filtered or curated reviews that hide negatives
Marketing content masquerading as product information
Comparison tools that only compare within one brand's range
triggers: New need arising requiring a category they haven't bought in before
Current product failing and requiring replacement research
Community discussion generating interest in a category
Significant purchase amount triggering research instinct
solution_principles: Because information gaps drive them to competitors who fill them, product content must be exhaustively complete ‚Äî specifications, limitations, comparisons, use-case guidance and honest acknowledgement of trade-offs.

Because they read the critical reviews first, review platforms must be unfiltered and brand responses to negative reviews must be genuine and resolution-focused ‚Äî managed or suppressed reviews are detected immediately.

Because the research process is as important as the purchase, content that adds genuine knowledge ‚Äî detailed guides, expert comparisons, technical deep-dives ‚Äî earns trust that converts to purchase even when a competitor's product is mentioned.

archetypes.name: The Bargain Hunter
archetypes.description: Shopping is a sport and the prize is the best price. I treat deal-finding as a skill I have developed and I am proud of it. I wait for sales, layer discount codes, use cashback platforms, compare across multiple channels simultaneously and share my best finds in communities where the sport is celebrated. Brand loyalty is entirely price-conditional ‚Äî I will buy premium when the discount makes it comparable to mid-range, and I will buy mid-range when the price is right. I switch without guilt and I switch without announcement.
archetypes.goals: I want to pay less than everyone else for the same or better product. I want to feel that my deal-finding intelligence has been rewarded. I want the system to be transparent enough that I can optimise it ‚Äî clear sale calendars, stackable promotions, cashback partnerships. I want the brands I buy from to respect my price sensitivity rather than treating it as a negotiating position to be overcome.
archetypes.needs: I need price history transparency, sale event calendars, clear promotion stacking rules and cashback platform compatibility. I research through deal communities, browser extension price trackers, price history tools and social media deal-sharing groups. I am deeply frustrated by manipulated price histories that make a 'sale' price look like a reduction when it has never been higher. I report and share these discoveries prominently.
archetypes.touchpoints: Deal communities and forums, price tracking browser extensions, cashback platforms, comparison sites and social media deal-sharing groups are my primary channels. I subscribe to brand email lists specifically for promotional codes and unsubscribe immediately after use. I engage with brand apps when they offer exclusive in-app pricing. Flash sale notifications are the highest-converting communication I receive.
expectations: Honest price history with no manipulation
Clear promotion stacking rules
Sale event calendars communicated in advance
Cashback platform compatibility
barriers: Manipulated price histories presenting inflated 'original' prices
Promotion codes that don't stack as implied
Price increases immediately before sale events
Loyalty programmes that don't reduce effective price
important_steps: Multi-channel price comparison at point of sale
solution_principles: Because price history manipulation is detected, shared and permanently damages trust, sale pricing must be genuinely reduced from a real ongoing price ‚Äî any artificially inflated reference price will be identified, exposed and amplified in deal communities.

Because they engage with promotions as a system to be optimised, promotion mechanics must be clear, consistent and genuinely stackable where implied ‚Äî obscure exclusion conditions discovered at checkout are shared as brand criticisms.

Because price-conditional loyalty can become genuine loyalty when a brand consistently delivers value, loyalty programmes must offer real price advantage ‚Äî points schemes that never meaningfully reduce cost are dismissed and mocked in the communities this archetype inhabits.

archetypes.name: The Values Voter
archetypes.description: Every purchase is a vote for the kind of world I want. I am not performing ethics ‚Äî this is a genuine and considered framework that shapes every buying decision. I research supply chains, check B-Corp certifications, read sustainability reports and verify claims against independent assessments. I will pay more and wait longer for a brand whose values genuinely match mine. I am as valuable a customer as any other archetype ‚Äî and as easy to lose, the moment I discover the values proposition was marketing rather than reality.
archetypes.goals: I want to build a consumption pattern I can defend ‚Äî to myself and to others. I want the brands I buy from to be using their commercial success to drive genuine positive impact: fair wages throughout the supply chain, environmental commitments with measurable progress, transparent reporting of what is not yet good enough. I want my purchasing power to be part of the solution, not part of the problem.
archetypes.needs: I need radical transparency ‚Äî supply chain visibility, material sourcing data, living wage commitments, carbon footprint data and honest reporting of current shortfalls alongside targets. I research through sustainability rating platforms, ethical consumer publications, B-Corp directories and NGO assessments. I am fluent in greenwashing and I identify it quickly. A single dishonest claim, once discovered, ends the relationship and generates public criticism.
archetypes.touchpoints: Ethical consumer platforms, sustainability rating apps, B-Corp directories, environmental NGO communications and ethical lifestyle communities are my primary discovery channels. I use brand websites to verify claims made elsewhere. I engage with brand social content when it demonstrates genuine commitment through evidence rather than positioning. I am a vocal advocate for brands that earn my trust and an equally vocal critic of those that betray it.
expectations: Complete supply chain transparency
Third-party verified sustainability claims
Honest reporting of shortfalls alongside targets
Carbon and environmental data at product level
barriers: Greenwashing detected in brand communications
Sustainability claims with no third-party verification
Environmental marketing without measurable commitments
Selective transparency that hides difficult parts of the supply chain
drivers: Brand as genuine actor not performer
triggers: New brand discovered through ethical consumer platform
Product category review triggered by new information
solution_principles: Because they verify every claim, sustainability communications must be built on third-party verified data with specific, time-bound targets ‚Äî and must honestly report what has not yet been achieved alongside what has.

Because a single exposed greenwashing claim generates public criticism that reaches their entire community, marketing must never claim more than operations have achieved ‚Äî the gap between brand values and business reality is the most dangerous content a brand can create.

Because genuine values alignment generates the most loyal and vocal advocates in any category, the investment required to genuinely earn this archetype's trust returns exponentially through community advocacy that no campaign budget can replicate.

archetypes.name: The Subscription Stacker
archetypes.description: I have restructured significant parts of my consumption around subscription and auto-replenishment models. I derive genuine satisfaction from the reduction of recurring decisions ‚Äî groceries, household essentials, personal care, content, software. I am not passive about my subscriptions: I review them regularly, optimise the mix and cancel what stops earning its place. I am loyal to subscription brands that continuously demonstrate value and I am ruthlessly efficient at identifying those that rely on inertia.
archetypes.goals: I want the parts of my consumption that don't require active choice to run themselves ‚Äî reliably, at good value, with the flexibility to adjust without penalty. I want subscription brands to treat my ongoing commitment as a relationship to invest in rather than a revenue line to protect through friction. I want the brands I subscribe to to improve the product over time as a reward for loyalty, not maintain it as a baseline while offering introductory discounts to new subscribers.
archetypes.needs: I need subscription management that is genuinely easy ‚Äî pause, adjust, skip and cancel must be as easy as subscribe. I research subscription options through comparison platforms, subscriber communities and content that evaluates value over time. I am deeply frustrated by cancellation journeys that require phone calls, dark patterns or multiple confirmation steps designed to induce abandonment of the cancellation attempt. I share these friction points publicly.
archetypes.touchpoints: Subscription comparison platforms, subscriber communities, brand apps and email communications are my primary channels. I engage with brand communications when they add genuine value ‚Äî new product additions, personalised recommendations, loyalty rewards. I treat cancellation flow friction as a significant brand negative and I am vocal about it in communities where other subscribers make decisions.
expectations: Pause, skip and adjust as easy as subscribe
Cancellation completable without a phone call
Loyalty rewarded with product improvement not just introductory pricing
Subscription management in a single dashboard view
barriers: Cancellation friction by design
New subscriber pricing better than loyal subscriber pricing
Inability to pause without cancelling
No single view of all subscription elements
triggers: New product category amenable to subscription model
Current subscription increasing price without value increase
Community recommendation of better subscription alternative
solution_principles: Because cancellation friction is experienced as manipulation and shared publicly as a brand negative, every subscription management action ‚Äî pause, skip, adjust, cancel ‚Äî must be completable in the same number of steps as subscription initiation.

Because they audit value regularly and cancel efficiently when value declines, retention must be built through continuous product improvement and loyalty rewards, not through friction ‚Äî the subscriber who stays because cancelling is hard is the same subscriber who writes the scathing review.

Because new subscriber pricing better than loyal subscriber pricing is an act of disrespect, the best available pricing must always be proactively offered to existing subscribers ‚Äî discovering a better deal is available only to new customers ends the relationship and begins a public narrative.

archetypes.name: The Social Shopper
archetypes.description: I do not trust brands ‚Äî I trust people. Every significant purchase is preceded by a community consultation: WhatsApp groups, comment sections, Reddit threads, creator recommendations, peer reviews. I am not a passive consumer of social proof; I am an active participant in the recommendation ecosystem. I share my purchases, review my experiences and contribute to the community intelligence that shapes the next wave of decisions. My trust is peer-given and it is the most powerful purchase motivator I have.
archetypes.goals: I want to buy things that my community has already validated ‚Äî not because I cannot decide for myself, but because peer experience is more reliable than brand promise. I want a brand experience so good that I cannot wait to share it. I want the brands I buy from to have earned community trust, not manufactured it through paid content or fake reviews. I measure purchase success by how much I enjoy telling people about it.
archetypes.needs: I need authentic peer reviews, creator recommendations I trust, community forums where real users share real experiences and brand engagement that feels human rather than corporate. I research through trusted creator content, community forums, friend recommendations and organic social media. I am immediately suspicious of suspiciously uniform positive reviews and I investigate further when a review pattern feels orchestrated.
archetypes.touchpoints: Trusted creator content, friend recommendations, community forums, organic social media and user-generated content are my primary channels. I discover brands through people, not through search. I engage with brand social media when it responds to real customers genuinely. I am a prolific sharer of purchase experiences ‚Äî positive and negative ‚Äî and my community takes my recommendations seriously.
expectations: Authentic and unmanipulated review ecosystem
Brand social media responses that feel genuinely human
Creator partnerships with trusted voices not paid performances
UGC celebrated and amplified by the brand
barriers: Fake or orchestrated review patterns
Brand responses to negative reviews that feel scripted
Creator partnerships that feel paid not genuine
Brand social presence that is broadcast not conversation
triggers: Creator content featuring a product authentically
Community thread about a product category
Brand interaction in social media that feels genuinely human
solution_principles: Because peer trust is the only trust that converts this archetype, review infrastructure must be genuinely unfiltered and brand responses to all reviews must be human, specific and resolution-focused ‚Äî managed positivity is detected and rejected.

Because creator partnerships are evaluated for authenticity, influencer and creator relationships must be built on genuine product alignment and honest disclosure ‚Äî a creator who clearly doesn't use the product destroys the trust they were engaged to build.

Because their post-purchase sharing shapes the next wave of buyers, every order, delivery and service interaction must be designed to generate content worth sharing ‚Äî the unboxing, the packaging, the personalisation, the service recovery are all shareable moments.

archetypes.name: The Considered Investor
archetypes.description: I buy less but I buy better. Every purchase is an investment decision ‚Äî I am looking for the highest quality, longest lifespan option in any category I buy in. I am not price-sensitive in the traditional sense: I will spend more to buy once rather than spend less to buy repeatedly. I research extensively, wait patiently for the right option and take genuine satisfaction in owning things that will outlast the average product in their category by a decade.
archetypes.goals: I want to build a set of possessions that are genuinely excellent ‚Äî made properly, built to last and worth the premium I paid. I want to reduce my total consumption over time by replacing quantity with quality. I want the brands I invest in to stand behind their products with genuine long-term warranty and repair capability. I measure purchasing success by how long I still have and use the thing I bought.
archetypes.needs: I need long-term quality evidence ‚Äî material specifications, independent durability testing, repairability ratings, warranty terms and end-of-life product take-back. I research through quality-focused communities, product longevity publications, repair-economy platforms and long-term user reviews rather than first-impression assessments. I am willing to wait months for a product to become available if the quality is right. I am deeply opposed to planned obsolescence.
archetypes.touchpoints: Quality-focused communities, product longevity publications, long-term ownership forums, craftmanship editorial and repair-economy platforms are my primary discovery channels. I engage with brand content that demonstrates commitment to quality and longevity ‚Äî material sourcing, manufacturing standards, lifetime repair programmes. I write detailed long-term ownership reviews that are highly valued in the communities I participate in.
expectations: Long-term warranty covering real failure modes
Repair programme as standard brand offering
Material and durability specifications at product level
Honest longevity claims backed by independent testing
barriers: Planned obsolescence in product design
Warranty that excludes the failure modes most likely to occur
No repair or spare parts programme
Longevity claims unsupported by independent evidence
triggers: Current product failing after insufficient lifespan
Discovery of a brand with genuine quality credentials
Category review triggered by quality dissatisfaction
solution_principles: Because they are buying for decades not seasons, warranty terms must cover the failure modes that actually occur over a long ownership period ‚Äî narrow exclusions discovered after failure are a permanent trust break shared in quality communities.

Because repairability is a core purchase criterion, lifetime repair programmes, spare parts availability and repair partnerships must be built into the brand proposition and prominently communicated ‚Äî they are the proof of the quality promise.

Because their long-term ownership reviews carry significant weight in quality communities, the product must deliver on its quality promise across years not just at initial purchase ‚Äî the five-year review is as commercially important as the launch review.

telecom.label: Telecom & Technology
telecom.description: Consumers and businesses navigating connectivity, contracts, devices and rapidly evolving technology across mobile, broadband, cloud and digital services.

archetypes.name: The Power User
archetypes.latin: Maximum ex Machina (Maximum from the Machine)
archetypes.description: I extract every capability from every device and plan I own. I read spec sheets for entertainment, follow network infrastructure announcements and know the difference between marketed and real-world performance before most people know the product exists. I do not call customer service ‚Äî I go directly to developer forums, signal maps and infrastructure status pages. My knowledge is genuinely superior to most frontline staff and I require peer-level engagement, not scripted support.
archetypes.goals: I want the best network performance available at any given moment and a plan that does not artificially restrict what I can do with it. I want transparent technical specifications ‚Äî real-world speeds, actual network coverage maps, honest latency data. I want to be rewarded for being a high-value, high-usage customer with access to capabilities and information before the general customer base.
archetypes.needs: I need developer-grade documentation, network performance data from independent sources, early access to new services and a support pathway that connects me directly with technically competent staff. I research through specialist technology forums, network performance communities, developer blogs and independent speed test aggregators. A peer recommendation from someone in my technical community carries more weight than any campaign.
archetypes.touchpoints: Technical forums, developer communities, independent network performance platforms, technology journalism and peer networks are my primary channels. I engage with brand content only when it provides genuine technical intelligence. I attend brand events when they offer genuine product access rather than managed demonstrations. I share detailed technical assessments that influence the next wave of technology-literate buyers.
expectations: Technically competent support without escalation
Real-world performance data not marketing metrics
Early access to new network capabilities
Developer-grade API and service documentation
barriers: Scripted support that cannot answer technical questions
Performance claims that don't match independent test data
Throttling or restrictions not disclosed in plan terms
Being routed through standard customer service for technical issues
triggers: Technical community discussion of a new capability
important_steps: Plan selection based on real-world data
mindset: Technically superior to most support staff
solution_principles: Because their technical knowledge exceeds most frontline staff, a direct technical support pathway ‚Äî staffed by engineers not scripts ‚Äî must exist and be accessible without standard escalation theatre.

Because they will independently verify every performance claim, all network metrics must be communicated as real-world data with methodology disclosed ‚Äî marketing metrics that diverge from independent test results destroy all credibility permanently.

Because their detailed public assessments influence technically literate buyers, early access programmes, beta services and developer documentation must be invested in as acquisition and retention strategy, not just product development tools.

archetypes.name: The Reluctant Stayer
archetypes.latin: Maneo Quia Timeo (I Stay Because I Fear)
archetypes.description: I am deeply dissatisfied but held in place by a combination of contract length, number portability anxiety, switching complexity and the sheer effort of changing something that is woven into my daily digital life. I complain loudly in surveys, to friends and occasionally in public ‚Äî but I stay. I have been waiting for the right moment or the right offer to leave for longer than I care to admit. One genuinely good proactive experience could convert me into an advocate. One more failure will finally overcome my inertia.
archetypes.goals: I want to feel that staying with my current provider is a choice I am making, not a trap I am in. I want a proactive gesture that acknowledges my tenure and my dissatisfaction ‚Äî not a retention offer only available because I threatened to leave. I want the problems that drove my dissatisfaction to be resolved, not managed. I want to stop thinking about changing providers because the experience has genuinely improved.
archetypes.needs: I need a proactive outreach that acknowledges the service gap, offers a meaningful remedy without requiring me to complain first, and gives me a compelling reason to believe things have changed. I research switching options periodically ‚Äî I know what competitors offer and I know the process. What stops me is effort, not loyalty. A single empathetic, proactive interaction that resolves my core issue could end years of dissatisfaction.
archetypes.touchpoints: I engage with my current provider primarily when something goes wrong. I use the app for account management but my experience of it is coloured by my overall dissatisfaction. I have explored competitor websites and comparison sites periodically. I discuss my frustrations with peers who occasionally provide the final push to switch. Social media is where I have expressed my dissatisfaction most publicly.
expectations: Proactive outreach before they have to complain
Retention offer not contingent on threat to leave
Genuine resolution not just acknowledgement
Recognition of tenure and loyalty in any offer made
barriers: Proactive outreach only when contract renewal is due
Best deals available only to new customers
Complaints resolved temporarily but core issue recurring
Switching process complexity used as implicit retention strategy
drivers: Proactive rather than reactive brand behaviour
An offer that makes staying a genuine choice not a default
triggers: Final service failure that overcomes inertia
Peer switching and reporting positive experience
Proactive outreach that genuinely addresses their issue
important_steps: Resolution and stay or final switch decision
solution_principles: Because they are one good interaction away from loyalty and one bad one away from defection, proactive retention must be based on behaviour signals ‚Äî not contract renewal dates ‚Äî identifying dissatisfaction before it becomes a complaint.

Because reactive retention offers available only after a threat to leave are experienced as manipulation, the best available offer must be proactively given to loyal customers ‚Äî the discovery that new customers get better deals is a defection trigger, not a retention tool.
Because their core issue has recurred through multiple contacts, resolution must be permanent and verified ‚Äî a follow-up call confirming resolution closed is as important as the fix itself.

archetypes.name: The Confused Adopter
archetypes.description: I buy technology out of necessity, not enthusiasm. I do not entirely understand what I have, what I am paying for or what my device and plan could do if I knew how to use them. I feel patronised by jargon, excluded by interfaces designed for power users and embarrassed to ask questions I worry should be obvious. I need patient, human, judgment-free support and a product that defaults to simplicity rather than requiring me to strip back complexity I was never equipped to manage.
archetypes.goals: I want my phone and my broadband to work ‚Äî reliably, simply and without requiring me to learn a new language. I want to pay a fair price for what I need and nothing more. I want to feel that the company I have given my money to considers it their responsibility to make sure I can actually use what I bought. I want to stop feeling stupid every time I need to interact with my technology provider.
archetypes.needs: I need plain language ‚Äî in plans, in contracts, in support interactions and in any communication the brand sends me. I need patient in-person support without time pressure. I need someone who will sit with me until the problem is genuinely resolved, not until the script says the call should end. I research through trusted people ‚Äî family members, friends, community groups ‚Äî not online. Word of mouth and personal recommendation are my primary purchase influences.
archetypes.touchpoints: In-store visits, phone support and trusted personal recommendation are my primary channels. I do not use comparison sites. I do not read spec sheets. I visit stores when I need help and I need the environment to feel welcoming rather than intimidating. I am deeply loyal to staff members who have helped me previously and I will return specifically to find them. My community and family network shapes every technology decision I make.
expectations: Plain language throughout every interaction
Patient support without time pressure
In-store staff who stay until genuinely resolved
No judgment for not knowing something
barriers: Technical jargon in communications and contracts
Digital-first support that assumes digital capability
Call time pressure preventing genuine resolution
Store environments designed for enthusiasts not novices
solution_principles: Because jargon is exclusion and exclusion costs customers, every communication ‚Äî contracts, bills, support scripts, in-store signage ‚Äî must be written for someone encountering this technology for the first time, not someone upgrading from a previous model.

Because their loyalty attaches to individual staff members, store teams must be trained and empowered to invest time without metric pressure ‚Äî a thirty-minute interaction that completely resolves the problem is worth more than three ten-minute contacts that don't.

Because digital-first service design leaves them without support, human channels must be genuinely easy to access and never positioned as the inferior or costly option ‚Äî for this archetype, human support is the product.

archetypes.name: The Value Switcher
archetypes.description: I switch provider every contract cycle and I do it without guilt, without sentiment and with considerable efficiency. I compare plans on a spreadsheet. I set a calendar reminder three months before my contract ends. I know exactly what I am paying, what a new customer at my current provider gets offered and what the best deal in the market is at any given moment. My loyalty is to value, not brand. The moment any provider offers a meaningfully better deal, I am a new customer.
archetypes.goals: I want maximum data, maximum speed and maximum features at minimum cost ‚Äî and I want to know that I have achieved that optimisation at any given moment. I want the switching process to be simple enough that the friction of changing never makes staying the easier option. I want a market where providers compete genuinely on price and features rather than obscuring their offering through complexity designed to prevent comparison.
archetypes.needs: I need completely transparent all-in pricing, standardised comparison metrics and a switching process that is fast and frictionless. I research through comparison platforms, deal aggregators, social media deal communities and current customer feedback on service quality at the providers I am considering. I engage with cashback offers, SIM-only flexibility and mid-contract upgrade rights as standard negotiating tools.
archetypes.touchpoints: Comparison platforms, deal aggregator sites, social media deal communities and provider switching portals are my primary channels. I engage with brands primarily at the point of acquisition and at the point of switching. I respond to retention offers only if they match or beat the best available market deal without requiring me to threaten departure. I share my switching experience and the deal I found in communities where others are planning their own switches.
expectations: All-in transparent pricing with no hidden fees
Switching process completable online in minutes
Retention offer that matches the market without requiring a threat
Contract terms in plain language with no obligation surprises
barriers: Pricing complexity designed to prevent comparison
Switching friction used as implicit retention
Best deals available only to new customers
Mid-contract charges that make switching financially punitive
drivers: Loyalty to the deal not the brand
triggers: Comparison site showing meaningfully better deal
Deal community post about a new offer
important_steps: Calendar reminder three months before contract end
New contract start and value confirmation
solution_principles: Because they will find the best deal regardless of brand relationship, the only retention strategy that works is genuine ongoing value ‚Äî the best available deal must be proactively offered to existing customers at renewal, not only to new ones.

Because pricing complexity is experienced as deliberate obfuscation, plans must be comparable on standardised metrics with all-in pricing visible at the first point of consideration ‚Äî complexity discovered at checkout generates public criticism.
Because switching friction is a temporary barrier not a loyalty driver, investment must go into making the ongoing product genuinely valuable rather than making the exit genuinely difficult.

archetypes.name: The Connected Family
archetypes.description: I manage connectivity for an entire household ‚Äî multiple devices, multiple ages, multiple usage patterns and one bill that needs to make sense of all of it. My eldest is gaming online, my partner is working from home, my youngest needs parental controls and I need a plan that handles all of this without requiring me to become a network engineer. I am not technically sophisticated and I am not price-insensitive ‚Äî I am time-poor and I need a provider that genuinely understands household connectivity as a system.
archetypes.goals: I want a single provider relationship that manages all of my household's connectivity needs ‚Äî mobile, broadband, streaming, devices ‚Äî in a way that is simple to understand and simple to manage. I want parental controls that work without daily intervention. I want enough bandwidth for everything to work simultaneously without negotiation over who is using the internet. I want one bill that is fair and one support line that can solve anything.
archetypes.needs: I need multi-line plan clarity, broadband and mobile bundling options, robust parental control tools and a single account dashboard that shows everything. I research through parent communities, household technology forums and peer recommendations from families with similar configurations. I am deeply frustrated by providers whose products are designed for individuals and retrofitted for households with inadequate family plan economics.
archetypes.touchpoints: Parent communities, household technology forums, peer family recommendations and in-store family plan consultations are my primary channels. I engage with brand communications when they address the household reality rather than the individual customer. I respond to bundle offers that simplify my account. I share my household provider experience in parent communities where others are making the same decisions.
expectations: Multi-line plan economics that make household sense
Parental controls that work without daily management
Single account view for all household lines and services
Bundle pricing that rewards household consolidation
barriers: Individual-focused plans with no genuine family economics
Parental controls requiring technical expertise to configure
Multiple bills for multiple services with no consolidation option
Support that treats each line as a separate customer relationship
triggers: Broadband and mobile contract ending at similar times
Peer family sharing positive bundle experience
solution_principles: Because the household is the actual customer unit, family plan pricing must deliver genuine economic advantage over individual lines ‚Äî a household that can calculate it is cheaper to stay with separate plans will stay with separate plans.

Because parental controls are a primary purchase driver, they must work reliably without technical expertise and must be manageable from the main account dashboard ‚Äî controls that require configuration at router level are not controls, they are aspirations.

Because household consolidation is the highest-value customer relationship, a dedicated bundle consultation that genuinely audits the household's needs and recommends the most appropriate configuration must be available in-store and online.

archetypes.name: The Security Conscious
archetypes.description: I am deeply aware of what digital connectivity costs in terms of privacy and security. I read the terms and conditions, I use VPNs, I have app permissions set to minimum, I know what data is being collected and I make choices accordingly. I am not paranoid ‚Äî I am informed. I expect my technology provider to treat data handling as a genuine responsibility, not a commercial opportunity. A single data breach or a discovered practice of selling user data ends the relationship instantly and publicly.
archetypes.goals: I want a connectivity provider whose data practices I can trust completely ‚Äî not because their privacy policy says the right things but because their operational behaviour confirms it. I want transparency about exactly what data is collected, how it is used and who it is shared with. I want security features built into the product by default rather than available as optional add-ons for an additional monthly fee.
archetypes.needs: I need independently verified privacy credentials, transparent data handling documentation and security features included in the standard plan. I research through privacy-focused technology journalism, independent security assessments, data breach databases and digital rights communities. I am acutely sensitive to the gap between stated privacy policy and operational practice. I share security-related findings in communities where others make technology decisions on similar grounds.
archetypes.touchpoints: Privacy-focused technology journalism, independent security research publications, digital rights organisations and privacy-aware technology communities are my primary channels. I engage with brand content when it demonstrates genuine operational commitment to privacy ‚Äî audit results, independent certification, transparent data reports. I am immediately suspicious of privacy marketing that is not backed by verifiable evidence.
expectations: Third-party verified privacy credentials
Data handling documentation in plain language
Security features included in standard plan not as add-ons
Immediate notification of any security or data incident
barriers: Privacy marketing without independent verification
Security features positioned as premium add-ons
Data breach notification delays
Terms and conditions that imply data commercialisation
drivers: Operational privacy not just policy privacy
Security by default not by addition
triggers: Community discussion of a provider's data handling
Contract renewal triggering comparison on privacy credentials
important_steps: Provider selection on verified privacy basis
Ongoing monitoring of provider data practices
solution_principles: Because they verify claims against independent assessments, privacy credentials must be third-party verified and audit results must be publicly available ‚Äî privacy marketing without evidence is not just ineffective, it actively triggers deeper investigation.

Because security features positioned as premium add-ons signal that privacy is a product not a principle, foundational security capabilities must be included in every plan as a baseline ‚Äî their absence communicates that basic security is optional.

Because a data breach is an immediate and permanent defection trigger, incident response must include immediate notification, clear explanation and concrete remediation ‚Äî delay or minimisation amplifies community criticism exponentially.

archetypes.name: The Small Business Operator
archetypes.description: I run a small business and my connectivity is the circulatory system of my operation. A dropped call is a missed client. A broadband outage is lost revenue.
