I do not have a dedicated IT department ‚Äî I am the IT department, alongside being the finance department, the operations department and the customer service department. I need a provider who understands that business connectivity is not the same as consumer connectivity, and that the stakes are qualitatively different.
archetypes.goals: I want connectivity that is reliable enough that I never have to think about it during a working day. I want a business account that gives me priority support when something fails ‚Äî not a consumer support queue that treats a business outage the same as a residential one. I want a single provider for mobile and fixed line that understands my business context and communicates with me accordingly.
archetypes.needs: I need guaranteed uptime commitments, priority business support, a dedicated account contact for anything above routine and clear SLA terms that are actually honoured. I research through small business networks, local business communities, peer operator recommendations and business-focused technology publications. I am deeply loyal to providers who have genuinely solved a business-critical problem quickly and deeply critical of those who have treated a business emergency as a standard ticket.
archetypes.touchpoints: Small business networks, local business associations, peer operator recommendations and business-focused technology publications are my primary discovery channels. I engage with providers through my dedicated business account contact when one exists. I evaluate providers on how they handle their first business-critical failure ‚Äî that interaction defines the relationship more than any acquisition experience.
expectations: Priority business support separate from consumer queue
Named account contact for business-critical issues
SLA terms that are genuinely honoured
Same-day resolution for business-affecting outages
barriers: Business issues routed through consumer support
SLA terms with sufficient exclusions to be effectively meaningless
No dedicated account contact
Resolution timelines designed for residential inconvenience not business impact
drivers: Peer recommendation from trusted fellow operator
triggers: Current provider failing during a critical business moment
Growth requiring more robust connectivity solution
solution_principles: Because a connectivity failure is a revenue event not an inconvenience, business support must be physically and procedurally separate from consumer support ‚Äî same-day resolution for business-affecting outages must be an operational commitment, not a best-effort aspiration.

Because the first business-critical failure defines the entire relationship, every business account must have a named contact who can be reached directly during an outage ‚Äî a ticket number is not a relationship.

Because peer recommendation is the primary acquisition channel for small business operators, the quality of crisis support becomes a marketing asset ‚Äî an operator whose emergency was resolved in hours becomes an advocate whose recommendation reaches their entire business network.

archetypes.name: The Silver Connector
archetypes.description: I am an older customer who has come to genuinely value staying connected ‚Äî to family, to health services, to the world. Technology is not my natural language but it has become important to me. I am not resistant to technology; I am dependent on the people who help me use it. I am deeply vulnerable to being sold products I do not need and deeply grateful when someone takes the time to make sure I can actually use what I have paid for. My loyalty, once given, is absolute.
archetypes.goals: I want to be able to video call my grandchildren, receive health alerts, participate in my community online and feel that the digital world has not left me behind ‚Äî and I want to do all of this without feeling that I am a burden on the people helping me. I want a provider who sees me as a valuable customer, not a transaction to be processed quickly or a vulnerable person to be sold to.
archetypes.needs: I need patient, human support as many times as necessary until I can genuinely do what I need to do independently. I need clear, large-format communications. I need pricing that is fair and uncomplicated. I need someone to help me set up my device properly the first time. I need to know who to call when something goes wrong ‚Äî and I need that person to know me. I discover new technology and providers entirely through trusted personal recommendation.
archetypes.touchpoints: Family recommendation, community group referrals, in-store visits and phone support are my entire channel set. I do not use comparison sites. I do not manage my account online. I respond to letters and calls. My family members often assist with technology decisions and communicate with providers on my behalf. A positive experience shared in my community group is the most powerful advocacy any brand will receive from me.
expectations: Patient support repeated as many times as necessary
Clear large-format communications
Fair pricing with no complexity
Named support contact or genuinely consistent team
barriers: Digital-only account management
Support time pressure
Small print and complex billing
Being sold products they cannot use or do not need
drivers: Feeling included in the digital world
triggers: Family member recommending a provider or device
Health condition making connectivity more important
Community group discussion about a provider
Current device becoming too old to function well
important_steps: Device and plan onboarding with patience
solution_principles: Because exploitation of this archetype is both ethically unacceptable and commercially catastrophic when discovered, sales processes for older customers must include an independent needs verification step that confirms the product sold is genuinely appropriate for the customer's actual usage.

Because their loyalty is absolute when earned, the investment in a patient, unhurried onboarding interaction pays back across years of low-churn, community-advocated loyalty ‚Äî it must never be treated as a cost to be minimised.

Because family members are often co-decision-makers and co-communicators, the relationship must be designed to include them naturally ‚Äî consent-based family account access and family-friendly support pathways must be standard, not exceptions.

education.label: Education & EdTech
education.description: Learners, parents and professionals investing in knowledge, credentials and futures across schools, universities, online platforms and professional development.

archetypes.name: The Credential Climber
archetypes.latin: Per Aspera ad Astra (Through Hardship to the Stars)
archetypes.description: I invest in education as career infrastructure. What matters to me is the credential at the end ‚Äî its recognition by employers, its weight in the jobs market and the career trajectory it unlocks. I am not here for the love of learning; I am here for the qualification that changes what doors open to me. I will sacrifice time, money and comfort for the right credential from the right institution. I am deeply outcome-focused and I evaluate everything through the lens of return on investment.
archetypes.goals: I want a qualification that my target employers recognise and value ‚Äî and I want evidence that alumni from this programme are doing the jobs I want. I want career support that goes beyond CV workshops to genuine industry network access. I want the learning process to be rigorous enough that the credential means something, and efficient enough that I emerge still employable in the industry I entered for.
archetypes.needs: I need employer recognition data, alumni career outcome statistics, industry partnership evidence and genuine career support infrastructure. I research through employer feedback on institutions, alumni LinkedIn profiles, graduate salary data and professional community discussions. I am deeply sceptical of institutions that promise outcomes without evidence and deeply loyal to those whose alumni networks deliver tangible career benefit.
archetypes.touchpoints: LinkedIn, professional communities, alumni networks, employer feedback on institutions and graduate outcome databases are my primary research channels. I engage with institution content when it demonstrates industry relevance and career outcome data. I attend open days with a list of career-outcome questions, not campus experience questions. My decision is career arithmetic, not campus atmosphere.
expectations: Employer-recognised credential with evidence
Alumni career outcome data available and honest
Genuine industry network access not performative
Career support that continues after graduation
barriers: Outcome claims not backed by data
Alumni network that exists on paper but delivers nothing in practice
Curriculum that trails industry reality by several years
Career services that offer generic support not sector-specific guidance
drivers: Return on time and financial investment
triggers: Target employer requiring a specific credential
Peer career advancement through a programme
mindset: Sceptical of outcome claims without data
solution_principles: Because credential value is measured by employer recognition and alumni outcomes, career outcome data must be specific, honest and regularly updated ‚Äî aggregate statistics that obscure industry or role distribution will be investigated and challenged.

Because alumni network access is as valuable as the curriculum, network activation must be a designed programme element not a passive directory ‚Äî facilitated introductions, mentorship structures and employer relationship events must exist and be delivered.

Because the investment is career infrastructure not personal enrichment, every curriculum decision must be validated against current industry requirements ‚Äî a credential from a programme whose content trails practice by three years is worth less than the paper it is printed on.

archetypes.name: The Curious Mind
archetypes.description: I learn for the love of it. Credentials are interesting but secondary ‚Äî depth, rigour and the intellectual satisfaction of genuinely understanding something are what I am here for. I connect ideas across disciplines, follow threads wherever they lead, engage with teachers as intellectual peers and am as likely to be found in the footnotes as the main text. I am the learner who asks the question that goes slightly beyond the scope of the course ‚Äî and I need educators who welcome that rather than redirecting me back to the syllabus.
archetypes.goals: I want my understanding to deepen continuously ‚Äî not just in the subject I am formally studying but in the connections between it and everything else I know. I want teachers who are genuinely expert and genuinely enthusiastic. I want an environment that rewards intellectual curiosity rather than merely certifying competent execution. I want to emerge from any learning experience with my understanding permanently changed.
archetypes.needs: I need quality of thinking above quality of production values. I need educators who go beyond the official scope and who respond to difficult questions with engagement rather than deflection. I research through academic publications, lecture series, intellectual podcasts, curated courses from genuine domain experts and reading communities. I am repelled by learning content that prioritises accessibility over accuracy and engagement over rigour.
archetypes.touchpoints: Academic publications, lecture series, intellectual podcasts, community-recommended courses and long-form educational content are my primary channels. I engage with platforms that curate for quality rather than scale. I participate in discussion communities where the level of engagement is genuinely sophisticated. I am an active contributor to the communities I learn in ‚Äî I teach as I learn.
expectations: Educators who engage with questions beyond the syllabus
Content that acknowledges complexity and nuance
Learning community with genuinely sophisticated engagement
Access to primary sources and original thinking
barriers: Oversimplification that sacrifices accuracy for accessibility
Educators who deflect difficult questions back to the syllabus
Assessment designed for minimum competency not maximum understanding
Community engagement at a lower intellectual level than expected
triggers: New subject area generating intense curiosity
Reading or conversation opening an intellectual rabbit hole
Community recommendation of a genuinely rigorous course
Career or personal transition creating new learning appetite
solution_principles: Because intellectual depth is the only metric that matters, content must be created by genuine domain experts who are permitted to go beyond the accessible and into the accurate ‚Äî rigor is the product, not a barrier to it.

Because they learn by engaging with peers at their level, community infrastructure must be curated for quality of discourse ‚Äî a discussion forum where every question is treated as equally valid is a forum that the Curious Mind leaves within a week.

Because they follow threads wherever they lead, content architecture must support non-linear exploration ‚Äî additional resources, primary sources and connected concepts must be accessible from every point in the learning journey, not sequestered behind a completed module gate.

archetypes.name: The Invested Parent
archetypes.latin: Pro Liberis Omnia (Everything for the Children)
archetypes.description: The actual student may be my child but I am as much a customer as they are ‚Äî and in many cases more so. I am investing enormously ‚Äî financially and emotionally ‚Äî in my child's education and I need to trust the institution completely. Communication that is vague, infrequent or generic does not reassure me; it activates my concern. I am not trying to take over my child's education; I am trying to be certain that it is in good hands. There is a difference, and the best institutions understand it.
archetypes.goals: I want my child to thrive ‚Äî academically, socially and emotionally ‚Äî and I want enough visibility into how that is happening to feel that my trust is justified rather than assumed. I want clear, proactive communication about progress, concerns and how the institution is responding to both. I want to feel that the people educating my child know who my child is ‚Äî not just their name and their grades.
archetypes.needs: I need proactive progress reporting, direct communication channels for concerns, transparent safeguarding and pastoral care information and a sense that my child is seen as an individual. I research through parent community networks, inspection reports, current parent feedback and peer recommendations from parents with children at the institution. I am deeply influenced by the warmth and specificity with which the institution communicates about my child personally.
archetypes.touchpoints: Parent community networks, school inspection reports, current parent testimonials, open events and direct communication with teaching staff are my primary channels. I engage with institution digital platforms for progress monitoring and communication. I attend every parent event. I discuss the school with other parents regularly and my experience of communication quality shapes my advocacy or concern.
expectations: Proactive progress communication not just response to queries
Teachers who know their child as an individual
Transparent pastoral and safeguarding information
Responsive direct channel to teaching staff
barriers: Generic progress reports that could apply to any student
Communication only when something is wrong
Opaque pastoral care processes
Teachers who clearly do not know their child specifically
drivers: Trust that is justified by evidence
Being seen as a partner not an inconvenience
triggers: Peer parent sharing a negative experience
solution_principles: Because generic communication is experienced as absence of attention, every parent communication must reference the specific child by name and with specific, observed detail ‚Äî a template with a name inserted is a template, not a relationship.

Because proactive communication is the primary signal of care, progress updates must be sent before parents ask, concerns must be raised before they escalate and good news must be communicated with the same urgency as bad.

Because parent community networks amplify both positive and negative experiences, the quality of communication must be consistent across all families ‚Äî selective attentiveness generates visible inequality that parent communities discuss and share.

archetypes.name: The Busy Upskiller
archetypes.description: I am a working professional trying to learn in the margins of a full life ‚Äî twenty minutes on a commute, a lunch break between meetings, a Sunday evening that could go either way. I am genuinely motivated to develop but attention and time are my scarcest resources. I will not complete a ten-week course on the strength of good intentions alone. I need content designed for intermittent engagement that delivers value in the first three minutes or I have already moved on to the next thing demanding my attention.
archetypes.goals: I want to emerge from learning with specific capabilities I can apply immediately ‚Äî not a comprehensive overview of a field that I will need months to synthesise into practical action. I want learning that respects my time by being ruthlessly focused on what matters most. I want progress that is visible even when sessions are short, and I want to feel that every minute I invest is returning more than a minute's worth of value.
archetypes.needs: I need micro-learning formats, mobile-first design, offline access, progress that saves automatically across devices and content that is directly applicable the day after learning. I research through professional community recommendations, employer-endorsed platforms and peer upskiller sharing. I am immediately deterred by long-form content with no progress indicators, mandatory sequential completion and platforms that don't work on a phone during a commute.
archetypes.touchpoints: Professional community recommendations, employer-endorsed platforms, LinkedIn Learning and peer upskiller communities are my primary channels. I engage with content that delivers in short sessions and platforms that remember exactly where I stopped. I respond to push notifications reminding me to continue ‚Äî when they are relevant and not excessive. I complete content when streaks, progress bars and peer accountability make consistency feel achievable.
expectations: Content completable in under fifteen minutes per session
Mobile-first design that works on a commute
Automatic cross-device progress saving
Immediate applicable output from every session
barriers: Long-form content with no micro-session option
Mandatory sequential completion blocking access to relevant sections
Platform that doesn't work on mobile
Progress lost when switching devices
triggers: New skill requirement identified at work
Performance review highlighting a development area
Peer professional sharing a useful platform
important_steps: Direct application of learning at work
solution_principles: Because attention is the scarcest resource, every piece of content must deliver its primary value within the first three minutes ‚Äî a learner who opens a module on a commute and finds no value in the first stop will close it and may not return.

Because sessions are short and irregular, progress must be automatically saved, perfectly resumed and visibly accumulated ‚Äî a learner who loses five minutes of progress loses the habit, not just the content.

Because applicability is the measure of value, every learning module must end with a specific, concrete action the learner can take in their next working day ‚Äî abstract knowledge without immediate application is invisible to this archetype.

archetypes.name: The Career Changer
archetypes.description: I am making a significant professional pivot ‚Äî from one industry, discipline or career level to something fundamentally different. This is not incremental upskilling; it is a reinvention. I carry the anxiety of starting over alongside the excitement of possibility. I need an educational pathway that acknowledges I am not a blank slate ‚Äî I have transferable skills, life experience and professional maturity ‚Äî while giving me the specific new capabilities I lack. I am highly motivated but acutely sensitive to whether the path I am on will actually get me where I need to go.
archetypes.goals: I want to successfully transition into a new career in the shortest credible timeframe. I want a programme that helps me reframe my existing experience as an asset in the new field, not a liability I am overcoming. I want genuine employer engagement ‚Äî not theoretical industry exposure. I want to know, from evidence, that people like me have successfully made this transition using this pathway.
archetypes.needs: I need transition-specific career support, portfolio or project-based learning that builds demonstrable capability, peer community with others in the same transition and direct employer engagement. I research through career change communities, bootcamp alumni networks, transition success story content and industry hiring manager perspectives on non-traditional backgrounds. I am deeply anxious about sunk cost ‚Äî the fear of investing significantly in a pathway that doesn't open the door I need.
archetypes.touchpoints: Career change communities, bootcamp and programme alumni networks, transition success story content and LinkedIn professional communities are my primary channels. I research extensively before committing and I value peer testimony from recent alumni above all other evidence. I engage with career advisors who have genuine industry connections rather than generic employability coaching.
expectations: Transition-specific career support not generic employability
Transferable skills reframing as part of the programme
Recent alumni in the same transition available to speak to
Direct employer engagement built into the curriculum
barriers: Generic career support not designed for career changers
Curriculum that treats them as having no prior experience
Alumni evidence that is outdated or from a different career context
No employer relationships in the target industry
drivers: Successful transition evidenced by recent alumni
Peer community in the same transition
triggers: Industry disruption making current career precarious
Life event creating space for reinvention
Discovery of a specific role or field generating genuine excitement
mindset: Deeply motivated when pathway is credible
solution_principles: Because sunk cost anxiety is the primary barrier to commitment, transition success data must be specific and recent ‚Äî not headline statistics but role-level, industry-level outcomes from alumni who made a similar transition within the last two years.

Because prior experience is an asset not a deficit, curriculum design must include explicit transferable skills mapping and career narrative coaching ‚Äî a career changer who can articulate their transition compellingly is more hireable than one with identical technical skills who cannot.

Because employer relationships determine transition success, direct employer engagement must be a designed programme element ‚Äî hiring manager panels, project briefs from real companies and facilitated introductions must happen during the programme, not promised as post-graduation possibilities.

archetypes.name: The Institutional Learner
archetypes.latin: More Maiorum (In the Way of the Ancestors)
archetypes.description: I believe in the value of established institutional education ‚Äî the campus experience, the structured curriculum, the peer cohort, the prestige of the name on the certificate. I am not dismissive of online or alternative learning, but I have chosen a traditional pathway because I believe it offers something that alternatives cannot replicate: the network formed in shared physical space, the academic rigour of a structured programme and the cultural capital of an institution with history. I understand what I am buying and I expect it to be delivered in full.
archetypes.goals: I want the complete institutional experience ‚Äî not just the qualification but the network, the memories, the access to alumni communities and the cultural formation that comes from three to four years in an environment of concentrated intellectual and social development. I want to graduate with relationships that last decades and an institution affiliation that opens doors in the rooms I want to enter.
archetypes.needs: I need the institution to deliver on the full promise of the experience ‚Äî campus community, faculty access, extracurricular richness, alumni network quality and career placement infrastructure. I research through rankings, campus visits, faculty publications and conversations with current students. I am acutely sensitive to the gap between what an institution presents and what it delivers ‚Äî I will investigate thoroughly before committing.
archetypes.touchpoints: University rankings, campus open days, faculty profiles, current student testimonials, alumni achievement tracking and institutional career placement data are my primary research channels. I engage with the institution's social and community channels as a prospective student and invest deeply in campus community once enrolled. I become an active alumni contributor when the experience has genuinely delivered on its promise.
expectations: Campus experience that matches the presentation
Faculty who are accessible beyond lectures
Alumni network that is genuinely active and valuable
Career placement infrastructure that produces evidenced outcomes
barriers: Gap between presented and delivered campus experience
Faculty who are present in title only
Alumni network that exists as a database not a community
Career services that offer generic support regardless of student ambitions
drivers: Peer cohort network formed in shared space
Complete campus experience not just curriculum
triggers: First career milestone requiring postgraduate credential
Career plateau addressable by institutional prestige
important_steps: Campus visit and current student conversations
solution_principles: Because they are purchasing a complete experience not just a curriculum, every element of the institutional promise ‚Äî campus community, faculty access, extracurricular life, alumni network ‚Äî must be delivered with the same quality as the academic offer.

Because alumni network value is a primary purchase driver, the network must be actively maintained and facilitated ‚Äî a database of contacts is not a network; events, introductions and community platforms that generate genuine connection must exist and function.

Because institutional reputation is built over generations and lost in cohorts, the gap between what is presented to prospective students and what is experienced by current ones must be managed with integrity ‚Äî overstatement discovered by enrolled students becomes the narrative for every subsequent open day.

archetypes.name: The Reluctant Returner
archetypes.description: I am returning to formal learning after a gap ‚Äî sometimes years, sometimes decades. I left education for reasons that made sense at the time and I am coming back with a mixture of genuine motivation and considerable anxiety about whether I still can. I worry about fitting in with younger students, about whether my brain still works the way it needs to for academic work, about whether the investment of time and money is justified at this point in my life. I need an institution that has genuinely designed for people like me, not one that accommodates me as an exception.
archetypes.goals: I want to prove to myself ‚Äî and perhaps to others ‚Äî that it is not too late. I want the qualification or capability I return for, and I want the process to be designed in a way that respects the life context I bring with me: employment, family, financial commitments. I want to succeed, and I need the institution to have genuine experience of helping people in my situation to do so.
archetypes.needs: I need flexible scheduling, genuine academic re-entry support, peer community with others returning to education and financial options that acknowledge I have adult financial responsibilities. I research through mature student communities, institution mature student testimonials and flexible learning programme reviews. I am deeply reassured by institutions that have specific returner pathways and deeply deterred by those where I would be an outlier in a system designed for school-leavers.
archetypes.touchpoints: Mature student communities, returner testimonial content, flexible learning programme reviews and institution open days designed for mature students are my primary channels. I research carefully and quietly before committing ‚Äî I am more risk-averse than a school leaver because the cost of a wrong decision is higher. I become a powerful advocate for institutions that genuinely supported my return.
expectations: Flexible scheduling that acknowledges adult responsibilities
Academic re-entry support that doesn't assume recent study
Peer community with other returners not just school leavers
Financial options designed for people with adult financial commitments
barriers: Systems designed entirely for school-leaver pathways
No specific mature or returner student support
Cohort culture where they feel visibly older
Financial models that don't acknowledge employment and family commitments
drivers: Proving it is not too late
Institutional genuine experience with mature students
triggers: Children reaching school age and freeing time
Career ceiling that requires a qualification to break through
Life event creating space and motivation for reinvention
solution_principles: Because the primary barrier is self-belief not capability, the first academic milestone must be designed to succeed ‚Äî a confidence-building early win that demonstrates their brain works and their experience is an asset, not a liability.

Because their life context is non-negotiable, flexible scheduling, asynchronous content access and assessment timing options must be genuine programme features not emergency accommodations granted on request.

Because they research quietly and thoroughly before committing, specific returner content ‚Äî testimonials from recent mature students, dedicated open events, transparent returner outcome data ‚Äî must be prominently available, not buried in general admissions information.

insurance.label: Insurance
insurance.description: Customers navigating a product they hope never to use, built on a promise they cannot fully verify until the moment it matters most.

archetypes.name: The Reluctant Buyer
archetypes.description: I buy insurance because I must ‚Äî legally, contractually or because the social cost of not having it has finally outweighed my indifference. I have no emotional relationship with the product. I resent the premium, I distrust the claims process and I select entirely on price. I switch without guilt at every renewal because loyalty to an insurance brand feels like a category error to me. The claim moment is the only interaction that could change any of this ‚Äî and I approach it expecting to be disappointed.
archetypes.goals: I want the lowest possible premium for the coverage level I am legally or practically required to hold. I want the renewal process to be invisible and the claims process, should I ever need it, to be fast, fair and free of the small-print traps I have always suspected were there. I want to pay as little as possible for a product I hope I never use.
archetypes.needs: I need comparison site visibility, transparent all-in pricing and a renewal process that either matches the market automatically or makes it trivially easy to switch. I research exclusively through price comparison platforms and I treat any provider loyalty pricing higher than new customer pricing as a betrayal. I am deeply cynical about the industry and easily confirmed in that cynicism. I respond to nothing except price ‚Äî until I make a claim.
archetypes.touchpoints: Price comparison platforms are my entire discovery and renewal channel. I arrive at a provider's website only after selecting them on a comparison site. I engage with the brand only during the claims process. I share claims experiences in review platforms and social media ‚Äî these are the moments when my voice reaches others still at the selection stage.
expectations: Lowest price matching the market at renewal
Claims process without small-print surprises
Digital-first self-service throughout
No loyalty penalty for existing customers
barriers: New customer pricing better than renewal pricing
Claims process revealing exclusions not clearly communicated at sale
Renewal communications that assume loyalty
Any friction in the switching process
important_steps: Public review based on claims experience
solution_principles: Because price is the only pre-claim differentiator, renewal pricing must be competitive with the open market from day one ‚Äî the loyalty penalty discovered at renewal is the primary driver of the public criticism that shapes other price-sensitive buyers' decisions.

Because the claims moment is the only opportunity to create a genuine relationship, the claims experience must be designed to exceed the low expectations this archetype carries into it ‚Äî a single fair, fast, frictionless claim converts a cynical customer into a rare and valuable advocate.

Because exclusions discovered at claim time are experienced as deliberate deception, coverage limitations must be communicated with the same prominence as the premium at point of sale ‚Äî small print that changes the product is a claims complaint waiting to happen.

archetypes.name: The Fortress Builder
archetypes.description: I buy comprehensive coverage across every life category because protecting my family and assets is a fundamental expression of care and responsibility. Insurance is not a grudge purchase for me ‚Äî it is a cornerstone of how I manage risk. I will overpay for peace of mind and brand reputation. I renew automatically unless trust is broken. I read my policies. I ask questions. I want a brand that treats me as a partner in risk management rather than a premium to be maximised.
archetypes.goals: I want complete confidence that every meaningful risk in my life is covered ‚Äî home, contents, health, life, travel, vehicles, income protection. I want a provider who proactively identifies gaps in my coverage rather than waiting for a claim to reveal them. I want a single trusted relationship that manages all of my insurance needs and knows enough about my life to advise rather than just sell.
archetypes.needs: I need a trusted advisor relationship, comprehensive product range, proactive coverage review and the confidence that claims will be handled fairly and quickly. I research through recommended brokers, trusted financial advisors and peer recommendations from people with similar asset and family profiles. I am deeply loyal to providers who have demonstrated integrity over time and deeply critical of those who reveal the limits of that integrity in a claims dispute.
archetypes.touchpoints: Trusted brokers, financial advisors, peer family recommendations and direct insurer relationships are my primary channels. I engage with providers through regular advisory conversations, not just at renewal. I expect my provider to know my life circumstances well enough to flag coverage implications of life changes I mention in conversation. I respond to proactive communication that demonstrates genuine knowledge of my situation.
expectations: Proactive coverage gap identification
Single relationship managing all policies
Claims handled with speed and fairness without dispute
Advisor who knows their life circumstances
barriers: Claims dispute after years of loyal premium payment
Coverage gap revealed by a claim rather than advisor
Generic renewal communication with no personal context
Advisor change without consultation and introduction
triggers: Peer experience of a claim ‚Äî positive or negative
solution_principles: Because the relationship is meant to be advisory not transactional, every life event mentioned in a client conversation must trigger a coverage review ‚Äî the advisor who spots a gap before a claim is the advisor who keeps the relationship for decades.

Because trust accumulated over years is destroyed in a single disputed claim, claims must be handled with the same generosity that the premium relationship implies ‚Äî the customer who has paid faithfully for twenty years deserves the benefit of the doubt, not the application of a narrow exclusion.

Because comprehensive coverage is the product promise, multi-policy consolidation must deliver genuine economic advantage alongside service advantage ‚Äî a loyal multi-policy customer paying more than a new single-policy customer is a relationship about to end.

archetypes.name: The Savvy Self-Insurer
archetypes.description: I am financially literate and I approach insurance as a mathematical question rather than an emotional one. I understand premium-to-risk ratios, excess optimisation, self-insurance reserves for low-value risks and the statistical likelihood of claims across categories. I buy insurance where the mathematics justify it and self-insure where they don't. I use comparison tools as a matter of course, understand policy exclusions before most sales teams do and configure my coverage precisely rather than accepting standard products.
archetypes.goals: I want the minimum coverage necessary to protect against catastrophic risk at the optimal premium. I want full policy customisation ‚Äî the ability to adjust excesses, add specific endorsements and remove standard inclusions that don't apply to my situation. I want a provider who treats my financial literacy as an asset and engages with me at the level of analysis I bring, rather than trying to sell me coverage I have already decided I don't need.
archetypes.needs: I need configurable products, transparent policy documentation in plain terms, online tools that allow me to model the premium impact of different coverage configurations and a claims process that is straightforward enough that the cost of using it doesn't exceed the value. I research independently ‚Äî policy comparison tools, financial planning communities, insurance reddit forums and actuarial literacy content. I am deeply frustrated by bundled products that force me to pay for coverage I don't want.
archetypes.touchpoints: Policy comparison platforms, financial planning communities, insurance forum discussions and direct insurer digital platforms are my primary channels. I engage with providers who offer genuine online configurability. I buy direct where possible to avoid broker margins I can eliminate through my own research. I share detailed policy comparisons in the communities where financially literate buyers make decisions.
expectations: Full online policy configurability
Transparent premium impact of each coverage choice
No forced bundling of unnecessary inclusions
Policy documentation that is accurate and complete without hidden exclusions
barriers: Forced product bundles with non-removable inclusions
Exclusion language that requires legal interpretation
Digital tools that configure appearance but not actual coverage
Sales pressure on coverage they have already decided against
drivers: Mathematical optimisation of premium to genuine risk
triggers: New product category requiring coverage consideration
Financial planning review triggering insurance audit
solution_principles: Because they understand the product better than most sales teams, digital tools must enable genuine policy configurability ‚Äî not the appearance of customisation that resolves to a standard product ‚Äî and every premium change must have a transparent mathematical rationale.

Because forced bundling is experienced as extraction not service, every inclusion in a standard product must be individually removable with premium credit applied ‚Äî a product that cannot be configured is a product that will lose this archetype to one that can.

Because they read the full policy document before purchase, every exclusion must be written in plain language and disclosed at the same prominence as the coverage summary ‚Äî exclusion language discovered after a claim is a regulatory risk as much as a customer experience failure.

archetypes.name: The Crisis Believer
archetypes.latin: In Necessitatibus Fides (Faith in Times of Need)
archetypes.description: I have experienced a major claim and I understand ‚Äî viscerally, not theoretically ‚Äî why insurance exists. The moment a flood destroyed my kitchen, a car accident totalled my vehicle or a health crisis arrived unexpectedly, the abstract product became a lifeline. How my provider behaved in that moment is the most important data point I have about any insurance brand. I am deeply loyal to those who delivered and permanently critical of those who didn't. My advocacy or criticism reaches further than most.
archetypes.goals: I want a provider I can trust completely when everything goes wrong ‚Äî not one that performed adequately in the easy moments and failed in the hard ones. I want the claims process to feel like the partnership I paid for, not a negotiation with an adversary. I want to know, before a crisis happens, that the company I have chosen will treat my claim the way I would want to be treated.
archetypes.needs: I need a provider with a claims reputation I can verify ‚Äî from people who have actually claimed, not from marketing materials. I research through claims experience reviews, financial ombudsman data, social media claims stories and peer recommendations from people who have navigated major claims. I am highly attuned to the difference between a brand that markets on claims experience and one that actually delivers it. I share my own experience extensively and my account carries significant weight.
archetypes.touchpoints: Claims experience review platforms, financial ombudsman decision databases, social media claims narratives and peer recommendations are my primary research channels. I engage with providers at claim time with the complete attention I give to few other interactions in my life. Post-claim, I become either the most valuable advocate or the most damaging critic a brand will encounter.
expectations: Claims handled with speed, fairness and genuine empathy
Single claims contact throughout the process
Regular proactive updates without needing to chase
Settlement that reflects the actual loss not the negotiated minimum
barriers: Claims handler changed mid-process
Exclusion applied that wasn't clearly communicated at sale
Settlement offer significantly below actual loss value
Needing to chase for updates on a claim in progress
drivers: Claims integrity verified by real experience
Provider who treats crisis as partnership not adversarial negotiation
Settlement that genuinely makes things right
Being treated as a person not a claim number
triggers: Renewal decision shaped entirely by claims experience
Peer crisis story triggering provider evaluation
Reading a claims review that confirms or challenges their experience
solution_principles: Because the claims moment is the product, every claim must be managed by a named handler who stays with it to resolution ‚Äî being transferred between handlers during a crisis is not a process failure, it is a trust failure.

Because settlement that feels fair creates loyalty that endures for decades, claims settlement must be approached with the goal of genuinely making the customer whole, not achieving the minimum defensible payment ‚Äî the difference in cost is marginal; the difference in advocacy value is enormous.

Because their post-claims narrative reaches prospective customers at the exact moment of provider selection, the quality of the claims experience is the most powerful marketing investment an insurer can make ‚Äî more influential than any campaign, more permanent than any brand positioning.

archetypes.name: The Young Invincible
archetypes.latin: Dum Iuvenis Sum (While I Am Young)
archetypes.description: I am young, healthy and statistically unlikely to need most of the insurance I am being asked to buy. Insurance feels like a tax on future problems I cannot yet imagine having. I buy what I must ‚Äî vehicle insurance because the law requires it ‚Äî and I defer everything else because the premium feels like money I could spend on my actual life today. I am not irresponsible; I am unconvinced. The brand that genuinely speaks to my reality rather than my parents' has an opportunity no other insurer has taken.
archetypes.goals: I want insurance that fits my actual life ‚Äî flexible, affordable, usage-based where possible and digital-native in every interaction. I want to pay for what I actually use and risk, not a standard product designed for a demographic I don't belong to yet. I want the category to stop treating me as a version of an older customer who hasn't arrived yet and start designing for who I actually am.
archetypes.needs: I need flexible, app-based, usage-sensitive products that start low and scale with my life. I research through peer recommendations, social media financial content and fintech review communities. I am deeply influenced by peers who have found insurance that feels relevant to them. I am most reachable through digital channels, short-form content and product experiences that feel designed for me rather than adapted for me.
archetypes.touchpoints: Social media financial content, peer recommendation, fintech review communities and app store reviews are my primary channels. I do not visit brokers. I rarely call anyone. I expect the entire product to be managed through an app. I engage with insurance brands when they speak my language ‚Äî flexible, transparent, digital, honest about risk probability rather than catastrophising to motivate purchase.
expectations: App-native product management
Usage-based or flexible pricing where possible
No phone calls required for routine management
Honest, non-catastrophising communication about actual risk
barriers: Products clearly designed for older demographics adapted down
Any requirement to call or visit for routine matters
Communication that catastrophises unlikely risks to motivate purchase
Inflexible annual policies with no mid-term adjustment
triggers: Peer having a positive insurance experience
Life event making risk suddenly real
important_steps: Legal or practical necessity triggering first purchase
mindset: Statistically rational about their own risk
solution_principles: Because the category hasn't designed for them, the first insurer to create a genuinely usage-based, app-native, flexible product for this life stage owns a cohort that will need increasingly comprehensive coverage for the next five decades ‚Äî acquisition cost now, lifetime value later.

Because catastrophising is the wrong communication strategy with someone who statistically understands their own risk, honest probability-based communication that acknowledges low risk while explaining the consequences of the tail scenario is more effective than the fear-based marketing designed for older demographics.

Because digital is not a channel preference but a baseline expectation, the entire product lifecycle ‚Äî purchase, management, adjustment, claims ‚Äî must be completable in the app without a phone call being the only option for anything that matters.

archetypes.name: The Small Business Protector
archetypes.description: I have built something ‚Äî a business, a livelihood, a reputation ‚Äî and I need it protected. Business insurance is not abstract to me. A liability claim, a property loss, a cyber incident, a key person event ‚Äî any of these could end what I have spent years building. I approach insurance with more engagement than most personal lines customers because the stakes are not theoretical. I need a provider who understands small business risk with the same seriousness I bring to it.
archetypes.goals: I want comprehensive business coverage that anticipates the specific risks of my sector and business model ‚Äî not a generic SME product with my business type checked in a dropdown. I want a provider who understands that business insurance is not just property and liability but also reputational risk, supply chain exposure, regulatory compliance and the human risks of a small team. I want to know that if something goes wrong, my business survives.
archetypes.needs: I need sector-specific coverage intelligence, a business insurance advisor who understands my industry and a claims process that moves fast enough to preserve my business operation while the loss is being addressed. I research through business association recommendations, sector-specific insurance specialists and peer operator reviews of claims experiences. I am deeply loyal to brokers and insurers who have demonstrated genuine understanding of my business type.
archetypes.touchpoints: Business association networks, sector-specific insurance brokers, peer operator recommendations and business-focused insurance review platforms are my primary channels. I engage with providers who speak the language of my sector without requiring explanation. I invest in the broker relationship and expect my broker to be genuinely proactive about risk identification in my business type.
expectations: Sector-specific coverage intelligence from the advisor
Claims response fast enough to preserve business operation
Coverage that reflects actual business risk not generic SME template
Broker who proactively identifies emerging risk in their sector
barriers: Generic SME product with no sector specificity
Claims process too slow to prevent business disruption
Advisor who doesn't understand the business model
Coverage gaps revealed by a claim rather than a review
drivers: Business survival in a loss event
Fast claims to minimise operational disruption
triggers: Regulatory change creating new compliance requirement
important_steps: Coverage configuration for actual risk profile
Annual risk review as business evolves
Claims initiation and business continuity during claim
solution_principles: Because generic SME products cannot address sector-specific risk, business insurance must be structured around industry-specific risk profiles, with advisors who have genuine expertise in the client's sector ‚Äî a broker who has to be educated about the business model before advising on coverage is the wrong broker.

Because business continuity during a claim is as important as the settlement, claims response for business policies must include immediate interim solutions ‚Äî replacement equipment, temporary premises, emergency cash flow ‚Äî not just a settlement timeline.

Because peer operator recommendation is the dominant acquisition channel, every positive claims experience becomes an acquisition asset ‚Äî a small business insurer with a reputation for handling claims with speed and integrity in a specific sector does not need to advertise in that sector.

archetypes.name: The Life Stage Navigator
archetypes.latin: Vita Mutat, Protectio Mutat (Life Changes, Protection Changes)
archetypes.description: I am at a significant life transition ‚Äî buying a home, having a child, getting married, approaching retirement ‚Äî and I suddenly understand that my insurance needs have changed in ways I have not yet addressed. I am not a regular insurance reviewer; I am activated by milestones. I arrive with genuine motivation but limited knowledge of what I now need. I need a guide, not a sales process. I need to feel that the advice I receive is genuinely in my interest rather than optimised for premium volume.
archetypes.goals: I want to arrive at the other side of this life transition with insurance coverage that genuinely reflects my new circumstances and genuinely protects what now matters most. I want guidance that helps me understand what I need without selling me what I don't. I want the process to be clear, unhurried and complete ‚Äî so that I don't discover a coverage gap at a crisis moment later.
archetypes.needs: I need life-stage-specific advice, clear explanation of how my circumstances have changed my risk profile and a coverage recommendation I can trust because it was clearly motivated by my interests. I research through life-stage content, financial advice platforms, life event communities and peer recommendations from people who recently navigated a similar transition. I am highly receptive to education and deeply suspicious of pressure.
archetypes.touchpoints: Life event communities, financial advice platforms, life-stage content from trusted sources and peer recommendations from recently transitioned people are my primary channels. I engage with providers who lead with education rather than product. I respond positively to content that helps me understand what I need before it asks me to buy. I am most receptive in the immediate window of a life event ‚Äî but most suspicious of providers who exploit that receptiveness.
expectations: Life-stage-specific advice not generic product presentation
Education before sales in every interaction
Unhurried consultation that covers everything
Coverage recommendation they can trust as genuinely in their interest
barriers: Generic product presentation with no life-stage context
Sales pressure during a period of high receptiveness and vulnerability
Incomplete advice that leaves coverage gaps to be discovered later
Advisor who doesn't acknowledge the emotional weight of the life transition
drivers: Confidence that new circumstances are properly covered
Trusted guidance rather than sales process
Complete coverage with no gaps discovered later
Advisor who understands their life transition
important_steps: Post-transition review as new normal establishes
solution_principles: Because life-stage transitions create genuine coverage gaps and genuine openness to guidance, the advice model must lead with education about what the transition changes in their risk profile ‚Äî a customer who understands why they need something is more likely to buy it and more likely to stay.

Because pressure during a high-emotion life event is experienced as exploitation, the consultation must be structured to inform completely before presenting any product ‚Äî an advisor who sells before they educate loses both the sale and the relationship.

Because coverage gaps discovered at crisis time are traced back to the advice given at the life event, the consultation must be designed to cover every coverage implication of the transition ‚Äî incompleteness discovered later is an advice failure that generates complaints, claims disputes and community criticism.

archetypes.name: The Digital Insurance Native
archetypes.latin: Omnia Uno Loco (Everything in One Place)
archetypes.description: I manage my entire insurance portfolio through apps, comparison platforms and digital-first insurers. The idea of calling a broker, posting a form or visiting an office to manage insurance is as foreign to me as paying for something with a cheque. I want my policies in a single digital wallet, my claims initiated with a photo, my renewals automatic unless I actively choose to change them and my advisor available via chat when I have a question. I am not a difficult customer ‚Äî I am a customer that most traditional insurers have simply not built for yet.
archetypes.goals: I want a single platform that manages all my insurance in one place ‚Äî policies, renewals, claims, documents, advisor chat. I want AI-assisted coverage recommendations based on my actual life data, not a questionnaire designed for someone else's life. I want my claims experience to be as good as my best app experience in any other category. I want insurance that feels like a product designed for 2025, not a product digitised from 1995.
archetypes.needs: I need a genuinely integrated digital insurance experience ‚Äî not a traditional product with a website in front of it. I research through fintech review platforms, app store ratings, digital insurance communities and social media financial content. I am deeply frustrated by digital interfaces that reach a phone call requirement for anything meaningful. I am an early adopter and my community follows my technology recommendations.
archetypes.touchpoints: Fintech review platforms, app store ratings, digital insurance communities, social media financial content and peer digital-native recommendations are my primary channels. I use the app for everything and evaluate the product primarily on the app experience. I engage with brands that are genuinely building new insurance infrastructure rather than wrapping old products in new interfaces.
expectations: Complete policy lifecycle manageable in the app
Claims initiated with photo and resolved digitally
AI-assisted coverage recommendations based on actual life data
Single platform for all policies with no phone calls required
barriers: Digital interface that requires a phone call for anything meaningful
Traditional product wrapped in a new interface
App that is beautiful but incomplete
Claims process that breaks out of digital into analogue
drivers: App experience quality as product quality
triggers: Discovery of a genuinely digital-native insurer
Traditional insurer digital failure frustrating beyond tolerance
Peer recommendation of a digital insurance platform
Life event requiring new coverage and prompting platform reassessment
solution_principles: Because digital is not a channel preference but a product requirement, every policy management action must be completable entirely within the app ‚Äî any process that breaks out to a phone call or a form is a product failure, not a service gap.

Because the app experience is how they evaluate the insurance product itself, investment in the digital platform must match investment in the underlying product ‚Äî a great policy with a poor app is a poor product to this archetype.

Because their community follows their technology recommendations, being the insurer they recommend to their peer network requires being the best digital insurance experience in any category they compare to ‚Äî the benchmark is not other insurers, it is the best app they use daily.

food_beverage.label: Food, Beverage & Restaurants
food_beverage.description: Diners, home cooks, delivery customers and food culture enthusiasts navigating taste, convenience, ethics, identity and the full spectrum of eating experiences.

archetypes.name: The Experience Diner
archetypes.latin: Edere Est Vivere (To Eat Is to Live)
archetypes.description: I eat out as a deliberate act of culture. The restaurant is a stage and the meal is an event ‚Äî I am not here to be fed, I am here to be moved. I research restaurants with the same rigour I bring to theatre or galleries. I understand technique, I can read a menu as a document of philosophy and I expect the front-of-house experience to match the kitchen's ambition. I am not precious ‚Äî I eat everywhere from street food to Michelin-starred rooms ‚Äî but wherever I eat, I want the experience to be fully intentional.
archetypes.goals: I want a meal that I remember ‚Äî for the dish, the service, the room, the conversation it sparked or the idea it planted. I want restaurants that are genuinely trying to do something, not just executing a formula. I want the experience to be coherent from the moment I book to the moment I leave ‚Äî every element in service of the same intention. I measure success by how much I want to talk about the meal afterwards.
archetypes.needs: I need discovery channels that surface genuine quality ‚Äî not sponsored placement or algorithmic popularity. I research through serious food journalism, chef-authored content, sommelier recommendations, critic reviews and peer food communities with discernment. I book in advance and I expect the reservation to be honoured with the same care I gave to making it. I respond to menus that tell a story and front-of-house teams who can articulate the thinking behind each element.
archetypes.touchpoints: Serious food journalism, critic reviews, chef social media, food community recommendations and restaurant reservation platforms are my primary channels. I engage with restaurant social content when it reveals the thinking behind the food ‚Äî not when it is lifestyle photography. I write detailed, considered reviews that carry weight in the communities where the next wave of experience diners makes decisions.
expectations: Reservation honoured with the care given to making it
Front-of-house who can articulate the kitchen's thinking
Coherent experience from booking to departure
Menu that demonstrates genuine culinary intention
barriers: Reservation not remembered or details lost
Front-of-house who cannot speak to the food with knowledge
Experience that doesn't match the ambition signalled by the menu
Being made to feel that the table is needed rather than wanted
triggers: New restaurant opening generating critical attention
Chef whose work they follow opening or changing direction
Anniversary or celebration requiring a meaningful meal
Food journalism piece sparking genuine curiosity
important_steps: Reservation as an investment of intent
solution_principles: Because the experience begins the moment the reservation is made, every pre-arrival touchpoint ‚Äî confirmation, reminder, pre-arrival communication ‚Äî must signal the same care and intention as the food itself.

Because front-of-house knowledge is as important as kitchen quality, every member of the service team must be able to speak with genuine knowledge about every dish, ingredient and decision on the menu ‚Äî a server who cannot explain the food is a gap in the experience.

Because their detailed public reviews shape the critical community's perception, the experience must be consistently excellent across every visit ‚Äî this archetype returns, brings peers and writes about both; inconsistency is noticed and communicated.

archetypes.name: The Convenience Converter
archetypes.latin: Cito et Satis (Fast and Good Enough)
archetypes.description: I eat to live, not the other way around. Food is fuel and convenience is the primary value proposition. I use delivery apps multiple times a week, I have a rotation of trusted restaurants I return to because I know what I will get, and I make decisions in under two minutes from opening an app to placing an order. I am not indifferent to quality ‚Äî but quality for me means reliability, not artistry. I need my food to arrive on time, at the right temperature, in the condition it left the kitchen.
archetypes.goals: I want excellent food delivered to me quickly, reliably and correctly. I want my preferences remembered so that the same meal I ordered three weeks ago is one tap away tonight. I want the delivery experience to match the quality of the food ‚Äî both arriving in the condition they were designed for. I want the entire experience to take the minimum possible amount of my attention.
archetypes.needs: I need fast, reliable delivery, accurate order fulfilment and a reordering experience that remembers everything. I research through the delivery app itself ‚Äî ratings, previous orders, featured sections. I am deeply loyal to restaurants that consistently execute at the standard they set and deeply unforgiving of those that don't ‚Äî a cold meal or a missing item generates an immediate review and a switch to the next option in my rotation.
archetypes.touchpoints: Delivery apps are my entire channel ‚Äî discovery, ordering, tracking and review all happen within one platform. I engage with restaurant profiles within the app, not through their own channels. I rate every order. I am highly influenced by delivery time, rating consistency and previous order history. I discover new restaurants through the app's recommendation engine and I am receptive to personalised offers.
expectations: Accurate delivery time from the first estimate
Order correct and complete every time
Food arriving at the right temperature
One-tap reordering of previous meals
barriers: Late delivery without communication
Missing or incorrect items
Food arriving at wrong temperature
Reordering process that requires rebuilding the cart from scratch
triggers: Hunger with no time or energy to cook
Familiar craving for a rotation restaurant
Personalised offer from a delivery app
Peer recommendation of a new delivery option
solution_principles: Because delivery time accuracy is the primary promise, estimated delivery times must be conservative rather than optimistic ‚Äî arriving five minutes early is invisible; arriving fifteen minutes late after a short estimate generates a one-star review and a switch to a competitor.

Because order accuracy is experienced as basic competence, a missing item is not a minor inconvenience ‚Äî it is a broken promise that removes this restaurant from the rotation until a generous and immediate resolution restores it.

Because reorder frictionlessness is a loyalty driver as powerful as the food itself, previous order data must be surfaced prominently and a previous order must be rebookable in one action ‚Äî the restaurant that remembers what they ordered becomes the default rotation choice.

archetypes.name: The Conscious Eater
archetypes.latin: Scio Quid Edam (I Know What I Eat)
archetypes.description: Every meal is a values decision. I think about where my food came from, who grew it, what it cost the environment and what it does to my body. I am not ascetic ‚Äî I love food and I eat with genuine pleasure ‚Äî but I want that pleasure to be clean. Plant-based, regeneratively farmed, locally sourced, seasonally driven, transparent about everything: these are not dietary restrictions but philosophical positions about how I want to participate in the food system. I spend more because I have decided this is worth spending on.
archetypes.goals: I want to eat beautifully and responsibly simultaneously ‚Äî and I want restaurants and food brands to make that possible without requiring me to compromise. I want provenance information to be as prominent as the menu description. I want brands that have done the work of sourcing ethically so that my choice of where to eat is also a choice I can stand behind. I want to know that the money I spend is going to the right people in the right amounts.
archetypes.needs: I need detailed provenance information, supplier transparency, seasonal menu commitment and honest communication about what is and isn't yet perfect in the sourcing story. I research through ethical food journalism, sustainable agriculture communities, certified food producer directories and chef philosophy content. I am immediately suspicious of sustainability language without operational evidence and I share my findings publicly.
archetypes.touchpoints: Ethical food journalism, sustainable food communities, chef philosophy content and provenance-transparent restaurant marketing are my primary channels. I engage deeply with brands that can name their suppliers, explain their sourcing decisions and acknowledge the ongoing journey. I am an active and influential community member whose recommendations carry real weight with other conscious eaters.
expectations: Named supplier provenance on the menu
Seasonal menu commitment evidenced not just stated
Honest acknowledgement of what is not yet perfect in sourcing
Dietary accommodation that doesn't treat plant-based as an afterthought
barriers: Sustainability claims with no supplier evidence
Plant-based options that feel like accommodation not intention
Seasonal menu language applied to non-seasonal sourcing
Greenwashing detected in brand communications
triggers: New restaurant discovered through ethical food community
Food journalism piece revealing a brand's genuine practice
Community recommendation of a newly opened conscious restaurant
important_steps: Long-term advocacy for genuinely aligned brands
solution_principles: Because provenance transparency is the product, supplier names must appear on the menu alongside the dish ‚Äî not in a separate section, not on the website only, not as a marketing statement but as an operational norm that demonstrates the relationship is real.

Because sustainability without evidence is marketing, every environmental claim must be backed by operational practice that is visible to the curious ‚Äî farm visit programmes, supplier story content and honest progress reporting build the trust that positions cannot.

Because their advocacy is peer-community-amplified and highly influential, a restaurant that genuinely earns the Conscious Eater's approval does not need to advertise in the communities where the next wave of conscious eaters makes decisions ‚Äî their recommendation reaches further than any campaign.

archetypes.name: The Social Feeder
archetypes.description: Food is the excuse, people are the point. I organise dinners, brunches, birthday celebrations and casual get-togethers around restaurant experiences because sharing a table is my primary mode of social investment. The restaurant is a setting for relationship and I evaluate it on how well it enables that ‚Äî noise levels, table size, menu breadth to accommodate everyone, service attentiveness without intrusiveness. The food must be good enough that it doesn't distract from the conversation. The experience must make everyone feel welcome.
archetypes.goals: I want every person at my table to leave happy ‚Äî with the food, the service, the atmosphere and the ease of the experience. I want the restaurant to understand that I am bringing people who are important to me and that making them feel welcome is making me feel that I made the right choice. I want the logistical complexity of a group booking ‚Äî dietary needs, timing, splitting the bill ‚Äî to be handled by the restaurant, not by me.
archetypes.needs: I need easy group booking, flexible menus with genuine dietary range, attentive but not intrusive service and a noise level that permits conversation. I research through trusted peer recommendations, group dining review content and restaurant social media that shows the atmosphere. I am deeply loyal to restaurants that have made my gatherings successful and deeply hesitant to return to those that made me anxious about my hosting choice.
archetypes.touchpoints: Peer recommendations for group dining, restaurant social media showing atmosphere, group booking platforms and review content specifically mentioning groups are my primary channels. I book well in advance for significant occasions and I expect the booking details to be remembered and acted upon. I share my group dining experiences publicly and my recommendation carries weight with the large social network I regularly bring to restaurants.
expectations: Group booking remembered and prepared for
Dietary needs accommodated without making anyone feel secondary
Service that attends to the table without interrupting the conversation
Bill management that doesn't create awkwardness
barriers: Booking details lost or not communicated to the service team
Dietary accommodations treated as burdens rather than requirements
Service that rushes the table or ignores it
Bill splitting that falls to the organiser to manage awkwardly
drivers: Everyone at the table leaving happy
Service that enables rather than interrupts the gathering
triggers: New restaurant opening with group-appropriate atmosphere
Peer recommendation for a specific occasion type
important_steps: Group booking with dietary and occasion details
solution_principles: Because the organiser carries the social risk of every hosting choice, group booking details ‚Äî party size, dietary requirements, occasion type ‚Äî must be acted upon visibly at arrival so that the organiser knows the restaurant was listening.

Because dietary accommodation is a social equity issue at a group table, every dietary need must be met with the same care as the standard menu ‚Äî a guest who receives an obviously inferior accommodation makes the organiser regret their choice.

Because their recommendation network is large and socially trusted, a restaurant that makes a group occasion genuinely successful acquires a recurring revenue relationship ‚Äî the Social Feeder returns for every occasion and brings a different group each time.

archetypes.name: The Health Optimizer
archetypes.latin: Corpus Est Templum (The Body Is a Temple)
archetypes.description: I treat food as functional medicine. Every meal decision is filtered through nutritional value, macronutrient composition, ingredient quality and the impact on my performance or recovery. I am not dieting ‚Äî I am operating. I eat out less than most because the average restaurant cannot meet my standards, and when I do eat out I need menus that are genuinely transparent about ingredients, preparation methods and nutritional content. I am not precious about it ‚Äî I explain clearly, I am easy to accommodate, but I need the kitchen to be honest with me.
archetypes.goals: I want to maintain my nutritional standards when eating out without turning every meal into a negotiation or an apology. I want restaurants and food brands to treat nutritional transparency as a normal customer expectation rather than a special request. I want menus that are designed with genuine ingredient intelligence, not just dishes that can be modified on request. I want my choices to make me feel as good the next day as they do in the moment.
archetypes.needs: I need full ingredient lists, preparation method transparency, macronutrient information and honest communication about allergens, cross-contamination and ingredient swaps. I research through nutrition-focused food communities, health-oriented restaurant guides and food brand transparency reports. I use delivery apps with nutritional filter functionality. I am deeply loyal to brands that make my standards easy to maintain and actively recommend them to my training and wellness community.
archetypes.touchpoints: Nutrition-focused food communities, health-oriented restaurant guides, fitness brand partnerships and delivery apps with nutritional filtering are my primary channels. I engage with restaurant content when it demonstrates genuine nutritional intelligence. I share my finding of genuinely accommodating restaurants in my fitness and wellness community ‚Äî a recommendation from me reaches a high-value, health-motivated peer group.
expectations: Full ingredient and preparation method transparency
Genuine dietary accommodation not just dish removal
Macronutrient information available on request
Honest allergen and cross-contamination communication
barriers: Vague ingredient descriptions on menus
Accommodation that removes rather than replaces
Staff who cannot answer ingredient questions confidently
Nutritional information available only on the website not in the restaurant
drivers: Nutritional standard maintenance when eating out
Kitchen that treats health requirements as normal
triggers: Discovery of a genuinely transparent food brand
Community recommendation of a health-accommodating restaurant
Dietary period requiring more careful eating out
important_steps: Menu research before visit or order
Meal consumption and next-day performance assessment
Community sharing of genuinely accommodating finds
mindset: Loyalty to brands that make standards easy
solution_principles: Because ingredient transparency is the baseline expectation, menus must include preparation method and key ingredient information as standard ‚Äî not as a separate allergy menu but as part of how every dish is described.

Because accommodation through subtraction communicates that health requirements were not considered in menu design, dietary options must be created with nutritional intelligence as a design input, not applied as a modification to a dish conceived without it.

Because their community is high-value and actively seeking trusted recommendations, a restaurant that genuinely accommodates nutritional requirements without fuss earns the advocacy of a peer group that eats out frequently, spends significantly and recommends specifically.

archetypes.name: The Value Hunter
archetypes.description: I have learned that the best food in any city is rarely served in the most expensive rooms. I search for quality that exceeds expectation at a price point that respects my budget ‚Äî and I find it constantly. Street food, family-run local restaurants, lunch menus at ambitious restaurants, happy hours, early bird deals: I navigate the food economy with the intelligence of someone who has eaten well for years without spending extravagantly. My recommendations are trusted by everyone who knows me because they always deliver more than the price suggests.
archetypes.goals: I want excellent food at a fair price ‚Äî and I define excellent as genuinely better than the money spent should produce. I want to discover the places that are beloved by the people who live near them but invisible to the people who only follow the guides. I want my food spend to deliver consistent positive surprise. I want to share my discoveries and be trusted for them.
archetypes.needs: I need discovery channels that surface genuine quality at accessible price points ‚Äî not just budget options but places where price and quality are genuinely misaligned in the customer's favour. I research through local food communities, neighbourhood dining guides, delivery app deep dives and peer recommendations from people with similar values. I am deeply suspicious of curated cheap eats lists that turn the places they feature into expensive tourist destinations overnight.
archetypes.touchpoints: Local food communities, neighbourhood dining guides, social media food discovery accounts, delivery app exploration and peer recommendations are my primary channels. I share my discoveries generously in communities where the currency is genuine local knowledge. I write reviews that communicate value specifically ‚Äî not just whether the food was good but whether it was worth what I paid and more.
expectations: Genuine quality that exceeds the price point
Hospitality that doesn't make a budget choice feel like a lesser one
Consistency ‚Äî the dish that was remarkable last time is remarkable again
Discovery through authentic community recommendation not curated tourism
barriers: Good value discovery being ruined by over-publicity
Inconsistency that makes returning a gamble
Being made to feel that budget dining is lesser dining
Price increases that remove the value that was the point
drivers: Consistent delivery on the original promise
triggers: Community discovery of a genuinely undervalued place
Neighbourhood exploration revealing a new option
Delivery app deep dive into a new cuisine area
Peer recommendation from a trusted food community member
solution_principles: Because value means quality exceeding expectation rather than simply low price, the food and hospitality must deliver more than the price implies ‚Äî a restaurant that charges little and delivers little is not good value, but one that charges little and genuinely delights is the Holy Grail for this archetype.
